answerChoices.Text: Transposition is the process of changing a key value during each round of encryption.
Diffusion is the process of changing the location of the plaintext within the ciphertext.
Substitution is the process of shuffling or reordering the plaintext to hide the original message.
Confusion is the process of exchanging one byte in a message for another.

questionText: When an Access Control List (ACL) utilizes a tables of subjects and objects showing actions each subject is authorized on individual objects, it can be BEST said to use:
explanation: A matrix-based model organizes tables of subjects and objects indicating what actions individual subjects can take upon individual objects. This concept is found in other model types as well, such as the lattice model. Access control to objects is often implemented as a control matrix. It is a straightforward approach that defines access rights to subjects for objects. The two most common implementations of this concept are ACLs and capabilities.

questionText: In the information flow models, which of the following statements can BEST describe the word “flow?”
explanation: In the information flow model, what relates two versions of the same object is called the flow. A flow is a type of dependency that relates two versions of the same object, and thus the transformation of one state of that object into another, at successive points in time. In a multilevel security (MLS) system, a one-way information flow device called a pump prevents the flow of information from a lower level of security classification or sensitivity to a higher level.

answerChoices.Text: Flow defines movement of data among subjects
A mathematical function that correlates two subjects
Flow is data between a subject and an object
A dependency that relates two versions of the same object

questionText: Which of the following shows the different modes a process can be found in a computer?
explanation:
Process states are the different modes in which a process may run. A process can operate in one of several states:
Ready: The process is ready to start processing when needed.
Waiting: The process is ready for execution but is waiting for access to an object.
Running: The process is being executed until the process is finished, the time expires, or the process is blocked or aborted.
Supervisory: The process is performing an action that requires higher privileges.
Stopped: The process is finished or terminated.

answerChoices.Text: Ready, waiting, running, supervisory and stopped
Running, stopped, interrupted, thread and program
Supervisory, slave, master, running and halted
In-que, processing, stopped, out of que and waiting

questionText: Which types of extinguisher is not recommended for rooms where equipment will be damaged by the water?
explanation: The listed extinguishers are defined as follows: Wet pipe extinguisher: Uses water contained in pipes to extinguish the fire. In some areas the water may freeze and burst the pipes causing damage. These are also not recommended for rooms where equipment will be damaged by the water. Dry pipe extinguisher: In this system the water is not held in the pipes but in a holding tank. The pipes hold pressurized air, which is reduced when fire is detected allowing the water to enter the pipe and the sprinklers. This minimizes the chance of an accidental discharge. Preaction extinguisher: Operates like a dry pipe system except that the sprinkler head holds a thermal-fusible link that must be melted before the water is released. This is currently the recommended system for a computer room. Deluge extinguisher: Allows large amounts of water to be released into the room, which obviously does not make a good choice where computing equipment will be located.

questionText: In which security mode does a user needs a signed non-disclosure agreement, proper clearance, a formal approval AND a valid need to know authorization to access all the information/data?
explanation:
Security modes summary


               Signed NDA         Proper Clearance    Formal Approval    Valid Need to Know
Dedicated      All information    All information     All information    All information
System high    All information    All information     All information    Some information
Compartmented  All information    All information     Some information   Some information
Multilevel     All information    Some information    Some information   Some information

questionText: When configuring the key lifetime, which factor should NOT be considered?
explanation: You should not consider the randomness of the key when configuring the key lifetime. The key lifetime should be affected by the user role and responsibilities, the application that they key is being used for, and the service provided by the key.

questionText: Which form of cloud computing has as its main security focus virtual machine management?
explanation: The main focus of an Infrastructure (sometimes called Integration) as a Service (IaaS) cloud computing deployment is virtual machine management.

questionText: What is NOT provided by DSS?
explanation: DSS does NOT provide confidentiality. It provides all the other concepts.

questionText: Which security service accomplishes its goal by identifying components and services as trusted or not trusted?
explanation: The listed security services perform the following functions: Boundary Control Services: Responsible for placing various components in security zones and maintaining boundary control between them. Generally this is accomplished by indicating components and services as trusted or not trusted. Access Control Services: Methods deployed to control access to sensitive material and to give users the access they need to do their job. Integrity Services: Ensure that data moving through the operating system or application can be verified to not have been damaged or corrupted in the transfer. Cryptography Services: Scrambling or encrypting information in transit and at rest. Auditing and Monitoring Services: Methods of tracking the activities of the users and of the system processes.

questionText: Which of the following Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria (TCSEC) rating levels refers to discretionary security protection?
explanation: The listed rating levels have the following characteristics: A1: Implies that the security assurance, design, development, implementation, evaluation, and documentation of a computer is performed in a formal and detailed manner. B1: Offers process isolation, the use of device labels, the use of design specification and verification, and mandatory access controls. B1 systems are used to handle classified information. B2: Refers to structured protection. This level is the lowest level to implement trusted facility management; levels B3 and A1 also implement it. Therefore, a B2 system should be resistant to penetration attempts. B3:- Refers to security domains. B3 systems should perform a trusted recovery. A B3 system should provide the monitoring and auditing functionality. A B3 system is used in environments that contain highly sensitive information and should be resistant to penetration attempts. Another feature of B3 rating is covert timing channel analysis. C1: Refers to discretionary security protection. To enable the rating process, subjects and objects should be separated from the auditing facility by using a clear identification and authentication process. C2: Refers to controlled access protection. A C2 system provides granular access control and establishes a level of accountability when subjects access objects.

questionText: Why should you assign a compromise date to a key that has been deactivated?
explanation: You should assign a compromise date to a key that has been deactivated so that you can retrieve information signed before the compromise occurred. Without the compromise date, you need to re-sign all data previously signed with the compromised key. You should never reactivate a compromised key.

answerChoices.Text: To know when you can re-activate the key
To know the lifetime of the key
To retrieve information signed before the compromise occurred
To know when you can delete the key

questionText: With which of the following does the key raise the lock metal piece to the correct height?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Cipher lock: Uses a key pad that requires the correct code to open the lock. Proximity authentication device: A programmable card used to deliver an access code to the device either by swiping the card or in some cases just being in the vicinity of the reader. Mantrap: A series of two doors with a small room between them. Warded locks: Lock with a spring-loaded bolt with a notch in it. The lock has wards or metal projection inside the lock with which the key matches and enables opening the lock. Tumbler locks: Lock with more moving parts than the warded lock with the key raising the lock metal piece to the correct height. Combination lock: Lock requires rotating the lock in a pattern, which if correct lines the tumblers up opening the lock. Cable lock: Vinyl-coated steel cables that connect to the laptop and then lock around an object.

questionText: You need to ensure that a message that you are transmitting to another user is not altered. You decide to use a hashing algorithm. Which of the following should you implement?
explanation: Of the options given, SHA-256 is the only hashing algorithm. AES and 3DES are symmetric algorithms. El Gamal is an asymmetric algorithm.

questionText: What is the FIRST step for a user to request a certificate if the certificate is planned to be used to send secure and authenticated email with a signature?
explanation:
Any participant that requests a certificate must first go through the registration authority (RA), which verifies the requestor’s identity and registers the requestor. After the identity is verified, the RA passes the request to the certificate authority (CA).

A CA is the entity that creates and signs digital certificates, maintains the certificates, and revokes them when necessary. Every entity that wants to participate in the PKI must contact the CA and request a digital certificate. The CA is the ultimate authority for the authenticity for every participant in the PKI and signs each digital certificate. The certificate binds the identity of the participant to the public key.

answerChoices.Text: Go to requesting agency to get security clearance
Register with the certification authority to verify identity
Go to the registration authority who verifies the user identity
Contact public key infrastructure (PKI) and request a certificate

questionText: Which of the following is a prolonged power increase?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Surge: A prolonged high voltage power increase Brownout: A prolonged power supply that is below normal voltage Fault: A momentary power outage Blackout: A prolonged power outage

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a hash function?
explanation: ECC is NOT a hash function. It is an asymmetric algorithm. All the other options are hash functions.

questionText: Which algorithm performs 3, 4, or 5 rounds of computations?
explanation: HAVAL performs 3, 4, or 5 rounds of computations. Tiger performs 24 rounds of computations. MD5 performs 4 rounds of computations. SHA-256 performs 64 rounds of computations.

questionText: Which security implementation framework model is the foundation of the noninterference model?
explanation: Although not as well-known as Biba and other integrity models, the Goguen-Meseguer model is the foundation of the noninterference model. With this model, the list of objects that a subject can access is predetermined

questionText: Which of the following security principles when applied to systems and devices can result in BETTER security and prohibit use of unwanted ports, protocols and services?
explanation: Related to the principle of least privilege, the principle of least functionality is that systems and devices should be configured to provide only essential or minimally required capabilities and specifically prohibit or restrict the use of functions, ports, protocols, and services.

questionText: Which type of extinguisher has a sprinkler head that holds a thermal-fusible link that must melt before the water is released?
explanation: The listed extinguishers are defined as follows: Wet pipe extinguisher: Uses water contained in pipes to extinguish the fire. In some areas the water may freeze and burst the pipes causing damage. These are also not recommended for rooms where equipment will be damaged by the water. Dry pipe extinguisher: In this system the water is not held in the pipes but in a holding tank. The pipes hold pressurized air, which is reduced when fire is detected allowing the water to enter the pipe and the sprinklers. This minimizes the chance of an accidental discharge. Preaction extinguisher: Operates like a dry pipe system except that the sprinkler head holds a thermal-fusible link that must melt before the water is released. This is currently the recommended system for a computer room. Deluge extinguisher: Allows large amounts of water to be released into the room, which obviously does not make this a good choice where computing equipment will be located.

questionText: An end user named Jim wants to access a website to order an item. The website uses an application account ‘WebAct’ to access the backend database named ‘BkEndDb.’ Which of the following statements is MOSTLY true?
explanation:
Objects are resources that a user or process wants to access, and subjects are the users or processes requesting access. If the resource is requesting access, it is a subject. If a resource is being accessed, it is an object. Many resources can be both objects and subjects.

Example. Jim, a user, wants to access an application. In this case, Jim is a subject, and the application is an object. If the application Jim uses needs to access a database, then the application is the subject, and the database is the object.

answerChoices.Text: Jim is subject, WebAct is subject and object, and BkEndDb is only object
Jim and WebAct are both objects, and BkEndDb is subject and object
Jim is subject and WebAct, BckEndDb are both subjects and objects
Jim, WebAct, BckEndDb can be all considered as subjects and objects

questionText: What is the difference between fail safe and fail secure devices in security?
explanation:
A product that is fail safe is unlocked when power is removed. Personnel therefore can enter or leave the area. A product that is fail secure is locked when power is removed. In this case, personnel can leave the area, but they must use a key to enter the area. These terms refer to the status of the secure side of the door. Most products provide free egress or exit whether they are fail safe or fail secure.

Fail-safe products should never be used for areas of high security. Simply cutting the power would give a threat actor access to the security area. Security professionals should ensure that public or general areas use fail-safe products, whereas secure areas, such as data centers, use fail-secure products.

answerChoices.Text: Fail safe systems lock on power off; Fail secure systems unlock on power off
Fail secure systems allow people to escape as they unlock on power off
Fail safe systems unlock on power off; Fail secure systems lock on power off
Fail secure systems protect human life and they are number one priority

questionText: When supporting a BYOD initiative, from which group do you probably have most to fear?
explanation: As a security professional, when supporting a BYOD initiative, you should take into consideration that you probably have more to fear from the carelessness of the users than you do from hackers.

questionText: Which type of cipher is the Caesar cipher?
explanation: The Caesar cipher is a mono-alphabetic substitution cipher. The Vigenere substitution is a polyalphabetic substitution.

questionText: Which CPTED concept applies to the entrances of the facility?
explanation: Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design (CPTED) refers to designing the facility from the ground up to support security. The three valid concepts are Natural Access Control: This concept applies to the entrances of the facility. It encompasses the placement of the doors, lights, fences, and even landscaping. It aims to satisfy security goals in the least obtrusive and aesthetically appealing manner. Natural surveillance is the use of physical environmental features to promote visibility of all areas and thus discourage crime in those areas. The idea is to encourage the flow of people such that the largest possible percentage of the building is always populated because people in an area discourage crime. Natural Territorials Reinforcement: The goal is to create a feeling of community in the area. It attempts to extend the sense of ownership to the employees.

questionText: Which model type maintains the proper security relationship between objects and subjects in each state of operation?
explanation: The listed model types are defined as follows: State Machine model: By examining every possible state the system could be in and ensuring that the system maintains the proper security relationship between objects and subjects in each state, the system is said to be secure. Multilevel Lattice Model: Developed mainly to deal with confidentiality issues and focuses mainly on information flow. Matrix-based model: Organizes tables of subjects and objects indicating what actions individual subjects can take upon individual objects. Noninterference model: Model less concerned with the flow of information and more concerned with a subject’s knowledge of the state of the system at a point in time; it concentrates on preventing the actions that take place at one level from altering the state presented to another level. Information Flow model: Model that focuses on controlling information flows that relate two versions of the same object.

questionText: In providing nonrepudiation by using digital signatures, who CANNOT deny the authenticity of a communication?
explanation: In providing nonrepudiation using digital signatures, the sender cannot deny the authenticity of a communication.

questionText: In a distributed environment, which of the following is software that ties the client and server software together?
explanation: In a distributed environment, middleware is software that ties the client and server software together. It is neither a part of the operating system nor a part of the server software. It is the code that lies between the operating system and applications on each side of a distributed computing system in a network.

questionText: Which of the following provides nonrepudiation?
explanation: A public key infrastructure (PKI) provides nonrepudiation. None of the other technologies provide nonrepudiation.

questionText: Which classification of threat is presented by a threat to perimeter security?
explanation: The listed threat types are defined as follows: System threat: Threats that exist not from the forces of nature but from failures in systems that provide basic services such as electricity and utilities. Natural threat: Physical threats that must be addressed and mitigated that are caused by the forces of nature. External threat: Threats from perimeter security or access to the building or room. Internal threat: Threats from those who may have some access to the room or building. Man-made threat: Physical threats faced from malicious and careless humans.

questionText: In which of the following does a platform act as a client or server or both?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Data warehouse: A repository of information from heterogeneous databases. Cloud computing: The centralization of data in a web environment that can be accessed from anywhere anytime. Grid computing: The process of harnessing the CPU power of multiple physical machines to perform a job. Peer-to-peer computing: Any client/server solution in which any platform may act as a client or server or both.

questionText: What is the purpose of a multiparty recovery key?
explanation: The purpose of a multiparty recovery key is to ensure that the key can be recovered. With this recovery key, separate entities each hold part of a key. The entities need to combine the pieces to reassemble the full key.

answerChoices.Text: To ensure that the key is not stolen
To ensure that the key can be distributed
To ensure that the key is strong enough
To ensure that the key can be recovered

questionText: In which of the following situations can a digital certificate be revoked?
explanation:
Revocation is the process whereby a certificate is revoked. CAs operating under NISTIR 7924 will make public a description of how to obtain revocation information for the certificates they publish, and an explanation of the consequences of using dated revocation information. This information will be given to subscribers during certificate request or issuance, and will be readily available to any potential relying party. Revocation requests must be authenticated.

A certificate will be revoked when the binding between the subject and the subject’s public key defined within the certificate is no longer considered valid. When this situation occurs, the associated certificate will be revoked and placed on the CRL and/or added to the OCSP responder. (Both CRL and OCSP are explained in the following sections.) Revoked certificates will be included on all new publications of the certificate status information until the certificates expire.

CAs should revoke certificates as quickly as practical upon receipt of a proper revocation request and by the requested revocation time.

answerChoices.Text: Binding between the object and the object’s private key in the certificate is invalid
Binding between the subject and the subject’s private key in the certificate is invalid
Binding between the object and object’s public key in the certificate is invalid
Binding between the subject and subject’s public key in the certificate is invalid

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of public cloud computing?
explanation: Loss of control of sensitive data is one of the concerns with public cloud computing.

questionText: Which security model implementation is a combination of Bell-LaPadulla model and the Biba models?
explanation: The Lipner model is an implementation that combines elements of the Bell-LaPadula model and the Biba model. The first way of implementing integrity with the Lipner model uses Bell-LaPadula and assigns subjects to one of two sensitivity levels system manager and anyone else and to one of four job categories. Objects are assigned specific levels and categories. Categories become the most significant integrity (such as access control) mechanism. The second implementation uses both Bell-LaPadula and Biba. This method prevents unauthorized users from modifying data and prevents authorized users from making improper data modifications. The implementations also share characteristics with the Clark-Wilson model in that it separates objects into data and programs.

questionText: Which security implementation framework model is represented as a directed graph, called a protection graph?
explanation: A system in the Take-Grant model is represented as a directed graph, called a protection graph. The subjects and objects of the computer system are the vertices and the access rights of subjects to objects are represented by arcs.

questionText: What are the PRIMARY objectives of Separation of Duties (SoD) control?
explanation:
Separation of duties (SoD) is an internal personnel control that distributes the tasks and associated privileges for a security process among multiple personnel. It is most often associated with an organization’s financial accounting policies whereby controls are put into place for issuing checks. The person inputting the payment information is usually a separate person than the one who signs or otherwise authorizes the checks after printing. In addition, organizations often implement policies whereby checks above a certain amount require two signatures.

SoD, as it relates to security, has two primary objectives: (1) to prevent conflict of interest, fraud, abuse, or errors and (2) to detect control failures, including breaches, data theft, and circumvention of security controls.

answerChoices.Text: Discourage two people working in the same shift
Prevents fraud or errors and detect breach or theft
Hiring different professionals for different work
Disable or discourage external employee attacks

questionText: Which of the following factors should be considered when designing a key management process?
explanation: When designing a key management process, all the listed options are important.

answerChoices.Text: Options a, b, c, and d only

questionText: Which countermeasure is designed to ensure that data moving through the operating system or application can be verified to not have been damaged or corrupted?
explanation: The listed countermeasures provide the following: Boundary Control Services: Responsible for placing various components in security zones and maintaining boundary control between them. Access Control Services: Methods to control access to sensitive material while giving users the access they need to do their job. Integrity Services: Services that ensure that data moving through the operating system or application can be verified to not have been damaged or corrupted in the transfer. Cryptography Services: Services designed to scramble or encrypt information in transit. Auditing and Monitoring Services: Services that track the activities of the users and of the operations of the system processes.

questionText: Your organization has recently signed a contract with another organization. As part of this contract, you must establish a public key infrastructure (PKI) for added security during inter-organizational communication. Which mechanism in the PKI is issued to users and includes a public key?
explanation: A digital certificate is the mechanism in the PKI that is issued to users and includes a public key. The CA creates and signs certificates. The RA verifies certificates. Steganography is an encryption method that hides data in another media type.

questionText: Which access control system operates in different security modes at various times, based on variables such as sensitivity of data, clearance level users, and users’ authorized actions?
explanation:
Security Modes

A mandatory access control (MAC) system operates in different security modes at various times, based on variables such as sensitivity of data, the clearance level of the user, and the actions users are authorized to take. The following sections provide descriptions of these modes.

Dedicated Security Mode

A system is operating in dedicated security mode if it employs a single classification level. In this system, all users can access all data, but they must sign a nondisclosure agreement (NDA) and be formally approved for access on a need-to-know basis.

System High Security Mode

In a system operating in system high security mode, all users have the same security clearance (as in the dedicated security model), but they do not all possess a need- to-know clearance for all the information in the system. Consequently, although users might have clearance to access an object, they still might be restricted if they do not have need-to-know clearance pertaining to the object.

Compartmented Security Mode

In the compartmented security mode system, all users must possess the highest security clearance (as in both dedicated and system high security), but they must also have valid need-to-know clearance, a signed NDA, and formal approval for all information to which they have access. The objective is to ensure that the minimum number of people possible have access to information at each level or compartment.

Multilevel Security Mode

When a system allows two or more classification levels of information to be processed at the same time, it is said to be operating in multilevel security mode. Users must have a signed NDA for all the information in the system and will have access to subsets based on their clearance level, need-to-know, and formal access approval. These systems involve the highest risk because information is processed at more than one level of security, even when all system users do not have appropriate clearances or a need to know for all information processed by the system. This is also sometimes called controlled security mode.

questionText: For which steps of the cryptographic life cycle is the CA responsible?
explanation: The CA is responsible for key creation. The RA is responsible for key distribution and management. The CRL is responsible for key revocation.
comments:
1/27/25 - adj per Au
