A password age policy configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it. An account lockout policy ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts.

answerChoices.Text: It configures the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused.
It configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it.
It ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts.
It configures the fewest number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

questionText: Which of the following is the most widely used web language?
explanation: The listed acronyms are defined as follows: Extensible Markup Language (XML): The most widely used web language. Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML): An XML-based open standard data format for exchanging authentication and authorization data between parties, in particular, between an identity provider and a service provider. Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP): An open-source application security project. This group creates guidelines, testing procedures, and tools to assist with web security. Open Vulnerability and Assessment Language (OVAL): A standard written in XML that provides open and publicly available security content. Its purpose is to standardize information between different security tools.

questionText: Which of the following controls considers multiple factors to help prevent inference?
explanation: The listed controls are defined as follows: Pre-validation controls: Are input controls that are implemented prior to submission to the application. These controls can occur on the client, the server, or both. Post-validation controls: Occur when an application's output is validated to be within certain constraints. Content-dependent access control: Bases access on the sensitivity of the data. Context-dependent access control: Bases the access to data on multiple factors such as previous history to help prevent inference.

questionText: Which of the following is the MOST preferred method to protect an information system device that has encryption already installed and access enabled with a remote connection?
explanation: For any IT professionals that need to access the device, a user account should be configured for the professional with the appropriate level of access needed. If a remote interface is used, make sure to enable encryption, such as SSL, to ensure that communication via the remote interface is not intercepted and read. Security professionals should closely monitor vendor announcements for any devices to ensure that the devices are kept up to date with the latest security patches and firmware updates.

answerChoices.Text: Warn users of consequences in case of a breach
Install latest security patches and firmware updates
Create discretionary access control on the device
Use virtual private network (VPN) for remote access

questionText: If controlling mechanisms involve limiting access of a user through software or hardware they are known as:
comments: 1/21/24 - This exam question does not include answer options. adj'd as per exp

questionText: Which of the following steps grants a user, permissions, rights to specific resources after signing proper documents?
Which of the following is the BEST way to prevent access aggregation?
explanation: To protect against access aggregation, organizations should implement permissions/rights policies that review an account when permissions or rights changes, both in escalation and de-escalation are requested. Administrators should ensure that any existing permissions or rights that the user no longer needs are removed. For example, if a user is moving from the accounting department to the sales department, the user account should no longer have permissions or rights to accounting resources.

answerChoices.Text: Block users from horizontal privilege escalation
Delete accounts that are not used for 60 days or more
Review accounts for permissions or rights changes
Check users for their vertical privilege escalations

questionText: How can geolocation be used as part of authentication?
explanation: Geolocation can be used as part of authentication because it provides where a person is. Geolocation may at some point be considered as a fourth authentication factor. The three types of authentication factors are as follows: Something you know – Knowledge Something you have - Possession Something you are - Characteristic

answerChoices.Text: It provides what a person knows.
It provides what a person possesses.
It provides what a person is.
It provides where a person is.

questionText: Which of the following is the main disadvantage of using single sign?
explanation:
SSO provides many advantages and disadvantages when it is implemented.  Advantages of an SSO system include

•    Users are able to use stronger passwords.
•    User and password administration is simplified.
•    Resource access is much faster.
•    User login is a one-time effort and can be more efficient.
•    Users need to remember only one set of login credentials.

Advantages of an SSO system include
After obtaining system access through the initial SSO login, a user is able to access all resources to which that user is granted access. Although this is also an advantage for the user (only one login needed), it is also considered a disadvantage because only one sign-on can compromise all the systems that participate in the SSO network.

•    If a user’s credentials are compromised, attackers will have access to all resources to which the user has access.

Although the discussion on SSO so far has been mainly about how it is used for networks and domains, SSO can also be implemented in web-based systems.

answerChoices.Text: Resources have only one gate way to sign into everything
If user’s credentials are compromised attackers can access all resources
Resources need time to share the password and become slow
If user’s credentials are compromised user’s personal data is at risk

questionText: What type of social engineering threat aims high level or high profile individuals in an organization?
explanation: Whaling is a type of phishing that specifically targets high-level executives or other high-profile individuals. Vishing is a type of phishing that uses a phone system or VoIP technologies. The user initially receives a call, text, or email that says to call a specific number and provide personal information such as name, birth date, Social Security number, and credit card information.

questionText: In which biometric system is the blood vessel pattern scanned?
explanation: In a retina scan, the retina’s blood vessel pattern is scanned. In an iris scan, the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows are scanned. In an eigenfeatures facial scan, the distance between the facial features are measured and recorded. In an eigenfaces facial scan, measurements of facial components are gathered and compared to a set of standard eigenfaces.

questionText: In which biometric system is the distance between facial features measured and recorded?
explanation: In an eigenfeatures facial scan, the distance between the facial features are measured and recorded. In an iris scan, the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows are scanned. In a retina scan, the retina’s blood vessel pattern is scanned. In an eigenfaces facial scan, measurements of facial components are gathered and compared to a set of standard eigenfaces.

questionText: Which type of attack is carried out from multiple locations using zombies and botnets?
explanation: A distributed DoS (DDoS) attack is a DoS attack that is carried out from multiple attack locations. Vulnerable devices are infected with software agents, called zombies. This turns the vulnerable devices into botnets, which then carry out the attack. Devices that meet TEMPEST standards implement an outer barrier or coating, called a Faraday cage or Faraday shield. A backdoor or trapdoor is a mechanism implemented in many devices or applications that gives the user who uses the backdoor unlimited access to the device or application. Emanations are electromagnetic signals that are emitted by an electronic device. Attackers can target certain devices or transmission mediums to eavesdrop on communication without having physical access to the device or medium.

questionText: Which controlling mechanisms has the LEAST uniformity and fairness of security?
explanation: In decentralized access control, personnel closest to the resources, such as department managers and data owners, oversee the access control for individual resources. This administration method ensures that those who know the data control the access rights to the data. However, decentralized access control can be hard to manage because there is no single entity responsible for configuring access rights. Decentralized access control, thereby loses the uniformity and fairness of security.

questionText: What kind of security management is MOST concerned with physical and logical access to assets such as networks, applications, and other information technology related equipment?
explanation: Identity and access management (IAM) is mainly concerned with controlling physical and logical access to assets and managing identities. These assets include computers, equipment, networks, and applications. Security professionals must understand how to control physical and logical access to the assets and manage identification, authentication, and authorization systems. Finally, the access control threats must be addressed.

questionText: Which of the following terms is BEST known for incriminating logs?
explanation:
Scrubbing is the act of deleting incriminating data within an audit log.

Audit trails detect computer penetrations and reveal actions that identify misuse. As a security professional, you should use the audit trails to review patterns of access to individual objects. To identify abnormal patterns of behavior, you should first identify normal patterns of behavior. Also, you should establish the clipping level, which is a baseline of user errors above which violations will be recorded. For example, your organization might choose to ignore the first invalid login attempt, knowing that initial failed login attempts are often due to user error. Any further invalid login attempts after the first would be recorded because they could be a sign of an attack. A common clipping level that is used is three failed login attempts. For security purposes, any failed login attempt above the limit of three would be considered malicious. In most cases, a lockout policy would lock out a user’s account after this clipping level is reached.

Audit trails deter attacker attempts to bypass the protection mechanisms that are configured on a system or device. As a security professional, you should specifically configure the audit trails to track system/device rights or privileges being granted to a user, and data additions, deletions, or modifications.

questionText: What kind of services the Software as a Service (SaaS), Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) are known as?
explanation:
Services refer to various forms of software and hardware functionalities that are essential for the operations of an organization's IT environment. These can include:

Software services: These are programs or processes that run in the background and perform specific tasks required by other software applications or the operating system.

Hardware services: This refers to the functionalities provided by physical devices, which can include metwork interface cards, network routers, switches, and firewalls. These devices often run their own software services to manage data routing, network security, and connection management.

Cloud services: These services are offered over the Internet by cloud service providers, including Software as a Service (SaaS), Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS).

questionText: In which biometric system are the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows measured?
explanation: In an iris scan, the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows are scanned. In a retina scan, the retina’s blood vessel pattern is scanned. In an eigenfeatures facial scan, the distance between the facial features are measured and recorded. In an eigenfaces facial scan, measurements of facial components are gathered and compared to a set of standard eigenfaces.

questionText: Which of the following are valid factors of authentication?
explanation:
After establishing the user, device, or service identification method, an organization must decide which authentication method to use.
Authentication methods are divided into five broad categories:
Knowledge factor authentication: Something a person knows
Ownership factor authentication: Something a person has or possesses
Characteristic factor authentication: Something a person is
Location factor authentication: Somewhere a person is
Time factor authentication: The time a person is authenticating

answerChoices.Text: What you know, what you have and how you do
What you have, what you know, who you are
Where you go, what you know and what time it is
Who you are, what you do, when you do and

questionText: You need to prevent users from reusing passwords over time. What password policy should you implement?
explanation: You should implement a password history policy to prevent users from reusing passwords over time.

questionText: Under which access control mechanism anything that is not expressly permitted is automatically forbidden by default?
explanation: In mandatory access control (MAC), subject authorization is based on security labels. MAC is often described as prohibitive because it is based on a security label system. Under MAC, all that is not expressly permitted is forbidden. Only administrators can change the category of a resource.

questionText: What type of attack uses a table that contains cryptographic hashes of passwords?
explanation: A rainbow table attack is similar to a birthday attack in that comparisons are used against known hash values. However, in a rainbow attack, a rainbow table is used that contains the cryptographic hashes of passwords. Using an up-to-date hashing algorithm (versus one that is outdated) is the first step in protecting against this type of attack. Salting is the process of randomizing each hash by adding random data that is unique to each user to their password hash, so even the same password has a unique hash.

questionText: Your organization has adopted the following user account policies: 1. All user accounts must be at least eight characters in length. 2. All user accounts can contain letters, numerals, and special characters. 3. Inactive user accounts should be disabled after 60 days of inactivity. 4. User accounts belonging to terminated employees should be disabled at time of termination. 5. Disabled user accounts should be deleted after one year of inactivity. You need to determine which step of the identity life cycle that each of these policies affect. Which statement is TRUE regarding these policies?
explanation: Both policy 1 and 2 affect the provisioning step of the identity life cycle. Policy 3 affects the review step of the identity life cycle. Policy 4 and 5 affect the revocation step of the identity life cycle.
comments: 1/20 - adj answer as per Exp

answerChoices.Text: Policy 1 affects the provisioning step of the identity life cycle.
Policy 1 and 2 affect the provisioning step of the identity life cycle.
Policy 2 and 3 affects the review step of the identity life cycle.
Policy 3, 4, and 5 affect the revocation step of the identity life cycle.

questionText: What is the term for a file in a MAC environment?
explanation: The term for a file in a MAC environment is an object. In a MAC environment, each subject and object is given a label. The term for a user in an MAC environment is a subject. The term for a clearance in a MAC environment is a privilege.

questionText: Which of the following statements about memory cards and smart cards is FALSE?
explanation: Memory cards are NOT also known as integrated circuit cards (ICCs). Smart cards are also known as ICCs.
comments: 6/25/25 - italicize FALSE

answerChoices.Text: A memory card is a swipe card that contains user authentication information.
Memory cards are also known as integrated circuit cards (ICCs).
Smart cards contain memory and an embedded chip.
Smart card systems are more reliable than memory card systems.

questionText: Which biometric method scans the colored portion of the eye?
explanation: The listed biometric methods are defined as follows: Vascular scan: A biometric scan that scans the pattern of veins in the user’s hand or face Signature dynamics: A biometric system that measures stroke speed, pen pressure, and acceleration and deceleration while the user writes his signature Retinal scan: A biometric scan that scans the retina’s blood vessel pattern Palm scan: A biometric scan that records fingerprint information from every finger as well as hand geometry information. Also referred to as a hand scan Keystroke dynamics: A biometric system that measures the typing pattern that a user uses when inputting a password or other predetermined phrase Iris scan: A biometric scan that scans the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows

questionText: After creating a backdoor in Advanced Persistent Threat (APT), how does a hacker USUALLY prevent discovery?
explanation:
An advanced persistent threat (APT) is an attack in which an unauthorized person gains access to a network and remains for a long period of time with the intention being to steal data. An APT does not aim to cause damage to the network or organization. Its main aim is to gain access to valuable information.

After attackers gain access to the network, they usually set up a backdoor. To prevent discovery, the attackers may erase logs (also known as covering their tracks), rewrite code, and employ other sophisticated evasion techniques. Some APTs are so complex that they require a full-time administrator. The attackers will work to establish backdoors with each successful breach of an internal system.

questionText: Which threat is considered a password threat?
explanation: A brute-force attack is considered a password threat.

questionText: During which step of the identity life cycle does auditing occur?
explanation: Auditing occurs during the review step of the identity life cycle. During the revocation step of the identity life cycle, user accounts are revoked or removed. During the provisioning step of the identity life cycle, user accounts are created. This step can also be referred to as creation.

questionText: Your organization has adopted the following user account policies: 1. All user accounts must be at least eight characters in length. 2. All user accounts should contain the user’s first name followed by the user’s last name initial. 3. Inactive user accounts should be disabled after 60 days of inactivity. 4. User accounts belonging to terminated employees should be deleted at time of termination. 5. Disabled user accounts should be deleted after 180 days of inactivity. Which statement affects the revocation step of the identity life cycle?
explanation: Policy 4 and 5 affect the revocation step of the identity life cycle. Policy 1 and 2 affect the provisioning step of the identity life cycle. Policy 3 affects the review step of the identity life cycle.

questionText: Which type of password includes a mixture of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters?
explanation: A complex password includes a mixture of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. A static password is the same for each login. A one-time password is used only once to log in to the access control system. A cognitive password is a piece of information that can be used to verify an individual’s identity by answering questions.

questionText: When three transactions were made in a short time frame from geographically different locations, a user’ credit card was blocked. What authentication factor the credit card company probably used in deciding to block the user’s credit card?
explanation: Time factor authentication authenticates a user based on the time and/or date the user is authenticating. For example, if certain users work only a set schedule, you can configure their accounts to allow them to log in only during those set work hours. However, keep in mind that such a limitation could cause administrative issues if overtime hours are allowed. Some organizations implement this type of authentication effectively by padding the allowed hours with an hour or two leeway for the start and end times. Credit cards use this feature effectively to protect their customers. If transactions take place in a short timeframe from geographically dispersed locations, credit cards will often block the second transaction.

questionText: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the permissions, rights and privileges?
explanation: Permissions are granted or denied at the file, folder, or other object level. Common permission types include Read, Write, Execute, and Full Control. Data custodians or administrators will grant users permissions on a file or folder based on the owner’s request to do so. Rights allow administrators to assign specific privileges and logon rights to groups or users. Rights manage who is allowed to perform certain operations on an entire computer or within a domain, rather than a particular object within a computer. While user permissions are granted by an object’s owner, user rights are assigned using a computer’s local security policy or a domain security policy. User rights apply to user accounts, whereas permissions apply to objects.

answerChoices.Text: Rights apply to objects; permissions apply to user accounts
Permissions or rights apply to user accounts and objects
Rights apply to user accounts; permissions apply to objects
Permissions are for departments. rights are for supervisors

questionText: Which type of password is the same for each login?
explanation: A static password is the same for each login. A one-time password is used only once to log in to the access control system. A complex password includes a mixture of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. A cognitive password is a piece of information that can be used to verify an individual’s identity by answering questions.

questionText: Which session management mechanisms are often used to manage desktop sessions?
explanation: Desktop sessions can be managed through screensavers, timeouts, logon, and schedule limitations. Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) Publication 201.2 and NIST Special Publication 800-79-2 are documents that provide guidance on proof of identity. Physical access to facilities can be provided securely using locks, fencing, bollards, guards, and closed-circuit television (CCTV). In Kerberos, the key distribution center (KDC) issues a ticket-granting ticket (TGT) to the principal. The principal sends the TGT to the ticket-granting service (TGS) when the principal needs to connect to another entity.

questionText: What is the purpose of a password age policy?
explanation: A password age policy configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it. A password history policy configures the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused. An account lockout policy ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts. A password length policy configures the fewest number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

answerChoices.Text: It configures the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused.
It configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it.
It ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts.
It configures the fewest number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

questionText: A kind of malware that replicates itself without user intervention is BEST known as:
explanation:
Malicious software, also called malware, is any software that is designed to perform malicious acts.

Worm: Any malware that replicates itself, meaning that it does not need another application or human interaction to propagate.

questionText: Which of the following is also BEST known as a need-to-know control?
explanation: In discretionary access control (DAC), the owner of the object specifies which subjects can access the resource. DAC is typically used in local, dynamic situations. The access is based on the subject’s identity, profile, or role. DAC is considered to be a need-to-know control.

questionText: Which of the following should NOT be included as part of the auditing strategy?
explanation: You should NOT ensure that the audit log is periodically scrubbed. Scrubbing an audit log removes only incriminating data and is considered illegal in many places. All the other statements should be included in an organization’s audit strategy.

answerChoices.Text: Ensure that the audit logs are backed up.
Monitor and manage the size of the audit logs.
Ensure that the audit log is periodically scrubbed.

questionText: What is the primary concern when establishing a password complexity policy?
explanation: The primary concern when establishing a password complexity policy is password strength.

questionText: What kind of biometric scan records the peaks and valleys of a user’s hand and its shape to allow access into a secure physical building?
explanation:
A hand geometry scan usually obtains size, shape, or other layout attributes of a user’s hand but can also measure bone length or finger length. Two categories of hand geometry systems are mechanical and image-edge detective systems. Regardless of which category is used, hand geometry scanners require less server space and processing time than fingerprint or finger scans.

A hand topography scan records the peaks and valleys of the hand and its shape. This system is usually implemented in conjunction with hand geometry scans because hand topography scans are not unique enough if used alone.

A palm or hand scan combines fingerprint and hand geometry technologies. It records fingerprint information from every finger as well as hand geometry information.
comments: 1/24/25 - adj per Exp

questionText: A Linux administrator needs to grant limited root privilege to an end user to run a service. What is the BEST way the user can be given access?
explanation:
When it comes to working with Linux, there are two ways to run administrative applications: (1) change over to the super user, also known as the root account, using the su command with a known password for the root or super user account, or (2) use the sudo command. With the sudo command, the user uses their regular or another user account but with root privilege. However, with the su command, the user is actually logged in to the root account. Also, the root privilege in the sudo command is valid only for a temporary amount of time. When that time expires, the user has to input a password again to regain root privilege.

Security professionals should ensure that use of the su command is greatly restricted. While the sudo command is a better choice, users should still use it only when it is strictly necessary.

answerChoices.Text: Supply the ‘root’ account password to the user for one day
Give permission to use ‘sudo’ command to run the service
Open access to the service to the end user for one day
End users cannot be given privileges to stop or start a service

questionText: Your organization has implemented a new security policy that requires that all user accounts should consist of the user’s first name followed by the user’s last name, separated using a period, as in john.doe. This new policy also states that when creating a new user account, administrators should assign the new user account a temporary password that must be changed by the user at the first login. Which step in the identity life cycle does this new policy affect the MOST?
explanation: The organization’s new security policy will affect the provisioning step in the identity life cycle. The reviewing step in the identity life cycle is responsible for monitoring and reviewing user accounts. Reviewing and monitoring are not considered separate steps in the identity lifecycle. The revoking step in the identity life cycle is responsible for the deletion of user accounts.

questionText: Which biometric method records fingerprint information from every finger as well as hand geometry information?
explanation: The listed biometric methods are defined as follows: Vascular scan: A biometric scan that scans the pattern of veins in the user’s hand or face Signature dynamics: A biometric system that measures stroke speed, pen pressure, and acceleration and deceleration while the user writes his signature Retinal scan: A biometric scan that scans the retina’s blood vessel pattern Palm scan: A biometric scan that records fingerprint information from every finger as well as hand geometry information. Also referred to as a hand scan Keystroke dynamics: A biometric system that measures the typing pattern that a user uses when inputting a password or other predetermined phrase Iris scan: A biometric scan that scans the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows

questionText: Your organization is implementing a new termination policy. As part of this policy, the user account of any employee who is terminated from employment must be disabled but retained for 30 days. During that 30-day period, the employee’s supervisor can request access and ownership transfer of any files and data. After 30 days, the account should be deleted. Which step in the identity life cycle does this new policy affect the MOST?
explanation: The organization’s new termination policy will affect the revoking step in the identity life cycle. The provisioning step in the identity life cycle is responsible for the creation of user accounts. The monitoring or review step in the identity lifecycle is responsible for monitoring user accounts to ensure that only active accounts are used. The review step in the identity life cycle is also responsible for all account modifications.

questionText: Which of the following statements regarding access control models are TRUE?
explanation: All the given statements regarding access control models are true.

answerChoices.Text: A database view is an example of a constrained user interface.
A time-of-day login limitation is an example of context-based access control.
A capability table lists the access rights that a particular subject has to objects.
An ACL lists all the access rights that subjects have to a particular object.

questionText: What well known language format is used by Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) that provides single sign on (SSO) capability?
explanation:
Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) allows users to access multiple web applications using one set of login credentials, thereby providing SSO. It passes authentication data in a set format between two parties, usually an identity provider (IdP) and a web application. SAML uses Extensible Markup Language (XML) format.

In a comparison of SAML and OAuth, SAML provides more control to enterprises to keep their SSO logins more secure, whereas OAuth is better on mobile devices.

questionText: In an access control mechanism, a table that lists access rights of a particular subject to various organizational objects can be BEST termed as:
explanation: Capabilities Table - A capability corresponds to a subject’s row from an access control matrix. A capability table lists the access rights that a particular subject has to objects. A capability table is about the subject.

questionText: What is TEMPEST?
explanation: TEMPEST is a United States government program that reduces electronic equipment emanations. The Patriot Act is a United States law established in 2001 to reduce restrictions on the searches of telephone, e-mail communications, medical, financial, and other records. Information warfare is a type of attack that involves attempting to exploit or corrupt an enemy's information to gain military or economic advantage. The Federal Computer Incident Response Center (FedCIRC) is the U.S. government entity responsible for dealing with federal computer security incidents that occur in civilian agencies.

answerChoices.Text: A United States law established in 2001 to reduce restrictions on the searches of telephone, e-mail communications, medical, financial, and other records
A type of attack that involves attempting to exploit or corrupt an enemy's information to gain military or economic advantage
A United States government program that reduces electronic equipment emanations
The U.S. government entity responsible for dealing with federal computer security incidents that occur in civilian agencies

questionText: What is the purpose of an account lockout policy?
explanation: An account lockout policy ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts. A password history policy configures the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused. A password age policy configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it. A password length policy configures the fewest number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

answerChoices.Text: It configures the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused.
It configures the maximum number of days a password can be used before the user must change it.
It ensures that an account can no longer be used after a certain number of unsuccessful login attempts.
It configures the fewest number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

questionText: You have been asked to design the identity management system for a new organization. You must implement appropriate policies to ensure that all access control needs are met. Which of the following issues should you consider?
explanation: When designing an identity management system, you should consider all the statements. Identity consistency is important so that administrators are better able to create and manage identities. System usability is important so that user IDs will be manageable. Complex systems are much harder to manage. System reliability is important so that users will be able to access the data. System scalability is important so that the organization can grow and expand.

questionText: Which of the following controls bases access on the sensitivity of the data?
explanation: The listed controls are defined as follows: Pre-validation controls: Are input controls that are implemented prior to submission to the application. These controls can occur on the client, the server, or both. Post-validation controls: Occur when an application's output is validated to be within certain constraints. Content-dependent access control: Bases access on the sensitivity of the data. Context-dependent access control: Bases the access to data on multiple factors such as previous history to help prevent inference.

questionText: At what point of access control mechanism does a user get permissions to use resources on a secure information system?
explanation: After a user, device, or service is authenticated, the user, device, or service must be granted the rights and permissions to resources. The process is referred to as authorization.

questionText: A handheld device that can transmit a one-time password (OTP) to an authentication server is BEST known as:
explanation:
The token device (often referred to as a password generator) is a handheld device that presents the authentication server with the one-time password. If the authentication method requires a token device, the user must be in physical possession of the device to authenticate. So although the token device provides a password to the authentication server, the token device is considered an ownership authentication factor because its use requires ownership of the device.

Two basic token device authentication methods are used: synchronous or asynchronous. A synchronous token generates a unique password at fixed time intervals with the authentication server. An asynchronous token generates the password based on a challenge/response technique with the authentication server, with the token device providing the correct answer to the authentication server’s challenge.

questionText: Over the past few years, your organization has merged several department networks into a single company network. As a result, each department has different methods for identity provisioning. Your company establishes a companywide provisioning policy to which all departments must transition. You have been asked to implement a solution that will allow users to use one account to log in to all systems across the departments. Which technology should you implement?
explanation: You should implement single sign-on (SSO) to allow users to use a single account to log in to all systems across the departments. Discretionary access control (DAC) and role-based access control (RBAC) are two access control models. Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) and intrusion prevention systems (IPSs) are hardware or software controls that either detect or prevent network intrusions.

questionText: In which MAC access security mode must all users possess the highest security clearance, but they must also have a valid need-to-know, a signed NDA and formal approval for all information to which they need access?
explanation: The listed security modes are defined as follows: Dedicated Security Mode: Employs a single classification level. In this system all users can access all data, but they must sign an NDA and be formally approved for access on a need-to-know basis. System High Security Mode: All users have the same security clearance but they do not all possess a need-to-know for all the information in the system. Compartmented Security Mode: All users must possess the highest security clearance (as in both dedicated and system high security), but they must also have a valid need-to-know, a signed NDA and formal approval for all information to which they have access. Multilevel Security Mode: Allows two or more classification levels of information to be processed at the same time.

questionText: You need to ensure that users implement passwords that include uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. What password policy should you implement?
explanation: You should implement a password complexity policy to ensure that users implement passwords that include uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.

questionText: Your organization has implemented a new security policy that requires that all user accounts that have been inactive for more than 60 days are disabled. If an account remains inactive for a year, the account should be deleted. You set up an auditing policy that will report inactive accounts to an administrator. Which step in the identity life cycle does this new policy affect the MOST?
explanation: The organization’s new security policy will affect the reviewing step in the identity life cycle. The provisioning step in the identity life cycle is responsible for the creation of user accounts. The revoking step in the identity life cycle is responsible for the deletion of user accounts. Disabling is not a step in the identity life cycle. In many cases, organizations choose to disable invalid user accounts for a period before the account is deleted. After an account is deleted, it may be impossible to access the files and data that belong to this account.

questionText: An account created for security context for running a background application on a 7x24x365 schedule on a Windows cloud server can be BEST called as:
explanation: A service account is an account created explicitly to provide a security context for services running on Windows or Unix computers. The security context determines the service’s ability to access local and network resources. Services that need accounts include Domain Name System (DNS), HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP), File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). Services that should not be running on a computer should be disabled and have the service accounts deleted.

questionText: After creating a backdoor in Advanced Persistent Threat (APT), how does a hacker USUALLY prevent discovery?
explanation:
An advanced persistent threat (APT) is an attack in which an unauthorized person gains access to a network and remains for a long period of time with the intention being to steal data. An APT does not aim to cause damage to the network or organization. Its main aim is to gain access to valuable information.

After attackers gain access to the network, they usually set up a backdoor. To prevent discovery, the attackers may erase logs (also known as covering their tracks), rewrite code, and employ other sophisticated evasion techniques. Some APTs are so complex that they require a full-time administrator. The attackers will work to establish backdoors with each successful breach of an internal system.

questionText: What is the authentication method BEST known as when it generates the password based on a challenge/response technique that has 45 minutes time limit between a challenge and response?
explanation: Two basic token device authentication methods are used: synchronous or asynchronous. A synchronous token generates a unique password at fixed time intervals with the authentication server. An asynchronous token generates the password based on a challenge/response technique with the authentication server, with the token device providing the correct answer to the authentication server’s challenge.

questionText: When vulnerable devices are infected with software agents, called zombies that cause various servers to shut down, what security factor is MOSTLY effected?
explanation:
A denial-of-service (DoS) attack occurs when attackers flood a device with enough requests to degrade the performance of the targeted device. Some popular DoS attacks include SYN floods and teardrop attacks.

A distributed DoS (DDoS) attack is a DoS attack that is carried out from multiple attack locations. Vulnerable devices are infected with software agents, called zombies. They turn the vulnerable devices into botnets, which then carry out the attack. Because of the geographically distributed bots and the very nature of the attack, identifying all the attacking botnets is virtually impossible. The botnets also help to hide the original source of the attack.

questionText: Which of the following controls are implemented prior to submission to the application?
explanation: The listed controls are defined as follows: Pre-validation controls: Are input controls that are implemented prior to submission to the application. These controls can occur on the client, the server, or both. Post-validation controls: Occur when an application's output is validated to be within certain constraints. Content-dependent access control: Bases access on the sensitivity of the data. Context-dependent access control: Bases the access to data on multiple factors such as previous history to help prevent inference.

questionText: Which of the following is a characteristic factor for authentication?
explanation: Biometrics is a characteristics factor for authentication. Passwords and PINs are knowledge factors for authentication. Smart cards are ownership factors for authentication.

questionText: When considering key distribution centers (KDCs) such as those used in Kerberos, which of the following statements are FALSE?
explanation: The master key is known by each user and the KDC, not ONLY the KDC. All the other statements are true.

answerChoices.Text: Session keys are distributed by the KDC.
Session keys are used only during a communication session.
The master key is only known by the KDC.
The master key encrypts traffic between the user and the KDC.

questionText: What is the MAIN purpose of authentication in access control mechanism?
explanation: To be able to access a resource, a user, device, or service must profess an identity, provide the necessary credentials, and have the appropriate rights to perform the tasks to be completed. Authentication, the second part of the process, is the act of validating a user, device, or service with a unique identifier by providing the appropriate credentials. When trying to differentiate between the two, security professionals should know that identification identifies the user, device, or service and authentication verifies that the identity provided by the user, device, or service is valid.

questionText: A kind of malware that replicates itself without user intervention is BEST known as:
explanation:
Malicious software, also called malware, is any software that is designed to perform malicious acts.

Worm: Any malware that replicates itself, meaning that it does not need another application or human interaction to propagate.

questionText: What is the MAIN disadvantage of creating and using cognitive passwords to access a security protected information system?
explanation: Cognitive passwords: This password type is a piece of information that can be used to verify an individual’s identity. This information is provided to the system by answering a series of questions based on the user’s life, such as favorite color, pet’s name, mother’s maiden name, and so on. An advantage to this type is that users can usually easily remember this information. The disadvantage is that someone who has intimate knowledge of the person’s life (spouse, child, sibling, and so on) might be able to provide this information as well.

answerChoices.Text: Their length is limited to 8 alphanumeric characters
They use only 3 to 5 pre-selected special characters
They can be guessed if you know the user intimately
They are very long nearly impossible to remember

questionText: Which type of malware spreads itself through network connections?
explanation: Spyware: Uses tracking cookies to collect and report on a user's activities to the spyware programmer. Virus: Malicious software (malware) that relies upon other application programs to execute itself and infect a system. Worm: A program that spreads itself through network connections. Trojan horse: Malware that is disguised as a useful utility, but embeds malicious code in itself. Adware: A software application that displays advertisements while the application is executing.

questionText: What is the FIRST step in designing and creating an access control process?
explanation: This first step in the access control process involves identifying all resources in the IT infrastructure by deciding which entities need to be protected. When identifying these resources, you must also consider how the resources will be accessed.

questionText: When using Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) over Secure Socket Layer (SSL) which of the following port numbers is used?
explanation: Based on X.500’s DAP, LDAP is simpler than X.500. LDAP supports DN and RDN, but includes more attributes such as the common name (CN), domain component (DC), and organizational unit (OU) attributes. Using a client/server architecture, LDAP uses TCP port 389 to communicate. If advanced security is needed, LDAP over SSL communicates via TCP port 636.

questionText: Which of the following is a standard written in XML that provides open and publicly available security content?
explanation: The listed acronyms are defined as follows: Extensible Markup Language (XML): The most widely used web language. Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML): An XML-based open standard data format for exchanging authentication and authorization data between parties, in particular, between an identity provider and a service provider. Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP): An open-source application security project. This group creates guidelines, testing procedures, and tools to assist with web security. Open Vulnerability and Assessment Language (OVAL): A standard written in XML that provides open and publicly available security content. Its purpose is to standardize information between different security tools.

questionText: A Linux administrator needs to grant limited root privilege to an end user to run a service. What is the BEST way the user can be given access?
explanation:
When it comes to working with Linux, there are two ways to run administrative applications: (1) change over to the super user, also known as the root account, using the su command with a known password for the root or super user account, or (2) use the sudo command. With the sudo command, the user uses their regular or another user account but with root privilege. However, with the su command, the user is actually logged in to the root account. Also, the root privilege in the sudo command is valid only for a temporary amount of time. When that time expires, the user has to input a password again to regain root privilege.

Security professionals should ensure that use of the su command is greatly restricted. While the sudo command is a better choice, users should still use it only when it is strictly necessary.

answerChoices.Text: Supply the ‘root’ account password to the user for one day
Give permission to use ‘sudo’ command to run the service
Open access to the service to the end user for one day
End users cannot be given privileges to stop or start a service

questionText: In which MAC access security mode do all users have the same security clearance but they do not all possess a need-to-know for all the information in the system?
explanation: The listed security modes are defined as follows: Dedicated Security Mode: Employs a single classification level. In this system all users can access all data, but they must sign an NDA and be formally approved for access on a need-to-know basis. System High Security Mode: All users have the same security clearance but they do not all possess a need-to-know for all the information in the system. Compartmented Security Mode: All users must possess the highest security clearance (as in both dedicated and system high security), but they must also have a valid need-to-know, a signed NDA and formal approval for all information to which they have access. Multilevel Security Mode: Allows two or more classification levels of information to be processed at the same time.

questionText: In which biometric system are measurements of facial components gathered and compared to a set of standard faces?
explanation: In an eigenfaces facial scan, measurements of facial components are gathered and compared to a set of standard eigenfaces. In an iris scan, the colored portion of the eye, including all rifts, coronas, and furrows are scanned. In a retina scan, the retina’s blood vessel pattern is scanned. In an eigenfeatures facial scan, the distance between the facial features are measured and recorded.

questionText: What is the term for a clearance in a MAC environment?
explanation: The term for a clearance in a MAC environment is a privilege. The term for a file in a MAC environment is an object. A label is required for each subject and object in a MAC environment. The term for a user in an MAC environment is a subject.

questionText: What is a Type I error in a biometric system?
explanation: False rejection rate (FRR): A measurement of valid users that will be falsely rejected by the system. This is called a Type I error.

questionText: Which MAC access security mode allows two or more classification levels of information to be processed at the same time?
explanation: The listed security modes are defined as follows: Dedicated Security Mode: Employs a single classification level. In this system all users can access all data, but they must sign an NDA and be formally approved for access on a need-to-know basis. System High Security Mode: All users have the same security clearance but they do not all possess a need-to-know for all the information in the system. Compartmented Security Mode: All users must possess the highest security clearance (as in both dedicated and system high security), but they must also have a valid need-to-know, a signed NDA and formal approval for all information to which they have access. Multilevel Security Mode: Allows two or more classification levels of information to be processed at the same time.

questionText: Which of the following statements regarding biometric access controls are TRUE?
explanation: The two statements that are TRUE are as follows: A Type I error represents the percentage of users who are falsely rejected. A Type II error represents the percentage of users who are falsely accepted. The CER is calculated using the Type I and Type II error values. The smaller the CER value, the more accurate the system.

answerChoices.Text: A Type I error represents the percentage of users who are falsely rejected.
A Type II error represents the percentage of users who are falsely accepted.
The Type II value is calculated using the CER and Type II error.
The smaller the CER value, the less accurate the system.
Statements a, b, and c only

questionText: Which of the following is the Microsoft’s implementation of Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP)?
explanation: Microsoft’s implementation of LDAP is Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), which stores and organizes directory data into trees and forests. It also manages logon processes and authentication between users and domains and allows administrators to logically group users and devices into organizational units.

questionText: An organization has an information system computer (ISC) with an industrial control software application (ICSA). The system has its access control defined by a special access card.  If a user needs to take a coffee break, which of the following BEST provides protection for the ISC?
explanation: Applications are installed digitally on devices. Logical access involves controlling who can digitally access or install applications on a device. For organizations, these applications may require that security professionals use IAM solutions to permit or deny access to users and roles. Permission may be limited to using the application or may be as expansive as allowing the users to install applications. These applications may use enterprise IAM or an in-application mechanism. Security professionals may need to use group policies to control the ability to install the applications on Windows devices. Physical access to applications is a slightly different matter. Some applications are installed via digital media. Security professionals should ensure that the media is stored in a secured location, such as a locked filing cabinet. Physical access to an application can also be obtained by gaining physical access to a device on which the application is installed. Devices should be configured to enter sleep or standby mode after a certain amount of user inactivity. In addition, users should be trained to digitally lock their devices when they leave their desks. This would ensure that an unauthorized user is not able to access the application.

answerChoices.Text: Stop ICSA and log off from ISC
Ask a colleague to watch during break

questionText: Your organization has adopted the following user account policies: 1. All user accounts must be at least 10 characters in length. 2. All user accounts should contain the user’s first initial followed by the user’s last name. 3. Inactive user accounts should be disabled after 90 days of inactivity. 4. User accounts belonging to terminated employees should be deleted at time of termination. 5. Disabled user accounts should be deleted after one year of inactivity. Which statement affects the review step of the identity life cycle?
explanation: Policy 3 affects the review step of the identity life cycle. Policy 1 and 2 affect the provisioning step of the identity life cycle. Policy 4 and 5 affect the revocation step of the identity life cycle.

questionText: Which type of password is a piece of information that can be used to verify an individual’s identity by answering questions?
explanation: A cognitive password is a piece of information that can be used to verify an individual’s identity by answering questions. A static password is the same for each login. A one-time password is used only once to log in to the access control system. A complex password includes a mixture of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.

questionText: An account created for security context for running a background application on a 7x24x365 schedule on a Windows cloud server can be BEST called as:
explanation: A service account is an account created explicitly to provide a security context for services running on Windows or Unix computers. The security context determines the service’s ability to access local and network resources. Services that need accounts include Domain Name System (DNS), HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP), File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). Services that should not be running on a computer should be disabled and have the service accounts deleted.

questionText: Which of the following is NOT part of the identity provisioning process?
explanation: Installing an application is NOT part of the identity provisioning process. The identity provisioning process includes creating, modifying, monitoring, and revoking accounts.

questionText: What is the final step in access control?
explanation: Authorization is the final step in access control. The order for the steps of access control is as follows: 1. Identification 2. Authentication 3.Authorization Accountability is not a step in access control. Accountability is the capability of an organization to hold users responsible for their actions.

questionText: What type of attack uses a table that contains cryptographic hashes of passwords?
explanation: A rainbow table attack is similar to a birthday attack in that comparisons are used against known hash values. However, in a rainbow attack, a rainbow table is used that contains the cryptographic hashes of passwords. Using an up-to-date hashing algorithm (versus one that is outdated) is the first step in protecting against this type of attack. Salting is the process of randomizing each hash by adding random data that is unique to each user to their password hash, so even the same password has a unique hash.

questionText: Which type of vulnerability assessment reviews standard practices and procedures that users follow?
explanation: Personnel testing is a type of vulnerability assessment hat reviews standard practices and procedures that users follow.

questionText: Which of the following are the BEST security checks that should be performed bimonthly?
explanation: The correct answer is vulnerability tests.
comments:
12/12/24 - adj per new Au

12/11/24 - query to Au

questionText: What is the correct order for penetration testing steps?
explanation: The correct order for penetration testing steps is as follows: 1. Discovery 2. Enumeration 3. Vulnerability analysis 4. Execution 5. Document findings

answerChoices.Text: Discovery, enumeration, vulnerability analysis, execution, document findings
Discovery, vulnerability analysis, enumeration, execution, document findings
Discovery, enumeration, execution, vulnerability analysis, document findings
Discovery, execution, enumeration, vulnerability analysis, document findings

questionText: Which of the following is a concern for a web application such as Google Docs?
explanation:
A web application is a computer program that uses a web browser and web technologies to perform tasks on websites. Web applications reside on web servers. Examples of web applications include webmail and document sharing applications, such as Gmail and Google Docs. The benefit of using a web application is that the user does not need to download an application locally or be concerned about software updates. However, companies that utilize third-party web applications have little control over their security and depend on the vendor for patching vulnerabilities. Because web applications are widely used today, organizations must ensure that their web applications remain secure and free of vulnerabilities. Web application vulnerability scanners are special tools that examine web applications for known vulnerabilities.

Popular web application vulnerability scanners include Grabber and Vega.

answerChoices.Text: Web application sends phishing mail to collect users’ personal data
End users have little or no control over the security of application
Internet and web applications are not reliable sources
End users never know the vulnerabilities of the application

questionText: What kind of testing can POSSIBLY include synthetic transactions?
explanation: Organizations must manage the security control testing that occurs to ensure that all security controls are tested thoroughly by authorized individuals. The facets of security control testing that organizations must include are vulnerability assessments, penetration testing, log reviews, synthetic transactions, code review and testing, misuse case testing, test coverage analysis, and interface testing.

questionText: As part of security assessment and testing, which of the following should be part of collecting security process data?
explanation: Key performance indicators should be part of collecting security process data. All the other components are part of testing security controls.

questionText: What is the second step of the information security continuous monitoring (ISCM) plan, according to NIST SP 800-137?
explanation:
The steps in an ISCM program, according to NIST SP 800-137, are: 

1.   Define an ISCM strategy.
2.   Establish an ISCM program.
3.   Implement an ISCM program.
4.   Analyze the data collected, and report findings.
5.   Respond to findings.
6.   Review and update the monitoring program.

questionText: What are the - reviews of the security status and reports for a system, application, or other environment – called?
explanation:
Security assessments are the reviews of the security status and reports for a system, application, or other environment. During this assessment, a security professional will review the results of the security tests, identify any vulnerabilities, and make recommendations for remediation. Security testing leads to security assessments.

Security professionals should prepare a formal security assessment report that includes all of the identified issues and recommendations. Also, they should document the actions taken based on the recommendations.

questionText: What is the difference between vulnerability test and a penetration test in terms of the duration of test?
explanation:
Comparison of Vulnerability Assessments and Penetration Tests
    Vulnerability Assessment    Penetration Test
Purpose    Identifies vulnerabilities that may result in compromise of a system.    Identifies ways to exploit vulnerabilities to circumvent the security features of systems.
When    After significant system changes. Schedule at least quarterly thereafter.    After significant system changes. Schedule at least annually thereafter.
How    Use automated tools with manual verification of identified issues.    Use both automated and manual methods to provide a comprehensive report.
Reports    Potential risks posed by known vulnerabilities, ranked using base scores associated with each vulnerability. Both internal and external reports should be provided.    Description of each issue discovered, including specific risks the issue may pose and specifically how and to what extent it may be exploited.
Duration    Typically several seconds to several minutes per scanned host.    Days or weeks, depending on the scope and size of the environment to be tested. Tests may grow in duration if efforts uncover additional scope.

answerChoices.Text: Vulnerability test must be stopped manually; Penetration test completes by itself in one hour
Penetration test takes several days; Vulnerability test can be done in few minutes/hours
Penetration tests must be stopped manually; Vulnerability test completes by itself in one hour
Vulnerability test takes several days ; Penetration test can be done in few minutes/hours

questionText: What is it known as if someone uses external agents to run scripted transactions against an application?
explanation: Synthetic transaction monitoring, which is a type of proactive monitoring, is often preferred for websites and applications. It provides insight into the availability and performance of an application and warns of any potential issue before users experience any degradation in application behavior. It uses external agents to run scripted transactions against an application. For example, Microsoft’s System Center Operations Manager uses synthetic transactions to monitor databases, websites, and TCP port usage.

questionText: When an organization conducts a penetration test without informing their own security team in advance, the test is BEST known as:
explanation: Double-blind test: This test is like a blind test except that the organization’s security team does not know that an attack is coming. Only a few individuals in the organization know about the attack, and they do not share this information with the security team. This test usually requires equal effort for both the testing team and the organization’s security team.

questionText: During which step of penetration testing are ping sweeps and dumpster diving attacks performed?
explanation: During discovery, ping sweeps and dumpster diving attacks can be performed to discover as much about the organization and its network as possible.

questionText: What types of vulnerability scanners are used in computer information security?
explanation:
There are two types of vulnerability scanners:

Passive vulnerability scanners: A passive vulnerability scanner (PVS) monitors network traffic at the packet layer to determine topology, services, and vulnerabilities. It avoids the instability that can be introduced to a system by actively scanning for vulnerabilities.

PVS tools analyze the packet stream and look for vulnerabilities through direct analysis. They are deployed in much the same way as intrusion detection systems (IDSs) or packet analyzers. A PVS can pick a network session that targets a protected server and monitor it as much as needed. The biggest benefit of a PVS is its ability to do its work without impacting the monitored network. Some examples of PVSs are the Nessus Network Monitor (formerly Tenable PVS) and NetScanTools Pro.

Active vulnerability scanners: Whereas passive scanners can only gather information, active vulnerability scanners (AVSs) can take action to block an attack, such as blocking a dangerous IP address. They can also be used to simulate an attack to assess readiness. They operate by sending transmissions to nodes and examining the responses. As a result, these scanners may disrupt network traffic. Active scanning should not begin until end users are notified about upcoming testing and the potential for network downtime. Examples include Nessus, Burp Suite, and IBM Security QRadar.

questionText: According to NIST SP 800-92, which of the following are facets of log management infrastructure? (Choose all that apply.)
explanation: According to NIST SP 800-92, log management functions should include general functions (log parsing, event filtering, and event aggregation), storage (log rotation, log archival, log reduction, log conversion, log normalization, log file integrity checking), log analysis (event correlation, log viewing, log reporting), and log disposal (log clearing.)

MultipleChoice.Text: ltpgt-opengeneral functions (log parsing, event filtering, and event aggregation)ltpgt-close
ltpgt-openstorage (log rotation, log archival, log reduction, log conversion, log normalization, log file integrity checking)ltpgt-close
ltpgt-openlog analysis (event correlation, log viewing, log reporting)ltpgt-close

questionText: Which type of testing is also known as negative testing?
explanation: Misuse case testing is also known as negative testing.

questionText: Which step in a penetration test proposes countermeasures?
explanation: A penetration test should include the following steps: Discovery: Obtain the footprint and information about the target. Enumeration: Perform ports scans and resource identification. Vulnerability mapping: Identify vulnerabilities in systems and resources. Exploitation: Attempt to gain unauthorized access by exploiting the vulnerabilities. Report: Report the results to management with suggested countermeasures.

questionText: What are the two ways of collecting logs using security information and event management (SIEM) products, according to NIST SP 800-92?
explanation: The two ways of collecting logs using security information and event management (SIEM) products, according to NIST SP 800-92, are agentless and agent-based.

questionText: As a security professional you want to do an XMAS Scan and close any unused open ports. To test, you send a packet FIN, PSH and URG flags set. If a port is open what flags are set in the packet that you would receive?
explanation:
They can perform the following types of scans:

TCP SYN scan: Sends a packet to each scanned port with the SYN flag set. If a response is received with the SYN and ACK flags set, the port is open.

TCP ACK scan: Sends a packet to each port with the ACK flag set. If no response is received, then the port is marked as filtered. If an RST response is received, then the port is marked as unfiltered.

Xmas scan: Sends a packet with the FIN, PSH, and URG flags set. If the port is open, there is no response. If the port is closed, the target responds with a RST/ACK packet.

The result of this type of scan is primarily for security professionals to determine whether ports are open that should be closed.

The most widely used network discovery scanning tool is Nmap

questionText:
A programmer reviewing code wants to test its validity for 

1) Required fields must be populated

2) Fields only accept data that has been validated 

3) Certain fields allow only pre-configured number of characters 

What kind of testing would be MOST suitable in this scenario?
explanation:
Misuse case testing, also referred to as negative testing, tests an application to ensure that the application can handle invalid input or unexpected behavior. This testing is completed to ensure that an application will not crash and to improve the quality of an application by identifying its weak points. When misuse cast testing is performed, organizations should expect to find issues. Misuse testing should include testing that looks for the following:

Required fields must be populated.

Fields with a defined data type can only accept data that is the required data type.

Fields with character limits allow only the preconfigured number of characters.

Fields with a defined data range accept only data within that range.

Fields accept only data that has been validated.

questionText: Which of the following is a hacker MOSTLY looking for, if they want to identify devices on network, connectivity relationships of the devices and the internet protocol (IP) addressing scheme in use?
explanation: Topology discovery entails determining the devices in the network, their connectivity relationships to one another, and the internal IP addressing scheme in use. Any combination of these pieces of information allows hackers to create a “map” of the network, which aids them tremendously in evaluating and interpreting the data they gather in other parts of the hacking process. If attackers are completely successful, they will end up with a diagram of the network.

questionText: What is the difference between a red team and a blue team in penetration testing?
explanation:
Red Team versus Blue Team

Penetration testing sometimes involves red team versus blue team exercises. The red team simulates attacks on a network, whereas the blue team is responsible for defending the network. Some red team - blue team exercises may include physical security tests, which means that a team may also try to social engineer its way into a “secure” facility - perhaps dressed up as a courier. Generally, a red team is more effective when it is composed of external consultants.

answerChoices.Text: A blue team supplies network and other inner details to a red team
A red team defends attacks on a network; a blue team simulates the network
A blue team is internal tester and a red team is a third party tester
A red team simulates attacks on a network; a blue team defends the network

questionText: How can an organization use the Key Risk Indicators (KRI) to their advantage?
explanation: By using key performance and risk indicators of security process data, organizations better identify when security risks are likely to occur. Key performance indicators (KPIs) allow organizations to determine whether levels of performance are below or above established norms. Key risk indicators (KRIs) allow organizations to identify whether certain risks are more or less likely to occur.

answerChoices.Text: Determine which risk framework can be adapted
Classify data depending on the risk they present
Identify which risks are more or less likely to occur
Comply with all the key risk indicator regulations

questionText: What kind of testing would you choose to test a software’s limits and discover flaws if any?
explanation:
Fuzz testing is a dynamic testing tool that provides input to the software to test the software’s limits and discover flaws. The input provided can be randomly generated by the tool or specially created to test for known vulnerabilities.

Fuzz testers include Untidy and Peach Fuzzer

questionText: You are tasked to write test cases against an application and are only provided with application requirements and specifications but not the source code. What type of testing would you choose as the MOST suitable?
explanation: Test coverage analysis uses test cases that are written against the application requirements specifications. Individuals involved in this analysis do not need to see the code to write the test cases. Once a document that describes all the test cases is written, test groups refer to a percentage of the test cases that were run, that passed, that failed, and so on. The application developer usually performs test coverage analysis as a part of unit testing. Quality assurance groups use overall test coverage analysis to indicate test metrics and coverage according to the test plan.

questionText: What kind of auditing is BEST suited if a federal government regulating body needs an audit report before granting certification to an organization?
explanation:
Security assessment, testing, and auditing occur in three manners: internal, external, and third-party. 

Internal assessment, testing, and auditing are carried out by personnel within the organization. External assessment, testing, and auditing are carried out by a vendor or contractor that is engaged by the company.

Sometimes third-party assessment, testing, and auditing are performed by a party completely unrelated to the company and not previously engaged by it. This scenario often arises as a result of having to comply with some standard or regulation or when accreditation or certification is involved. Many certifying or regulating bodies may require engagement of a third party that has not had a previous relationship with the organization being assessed. In this case, the certifying body will work with the organization to engage an approved third party.

answerChoices.Text: External audit from within the organization
Audit from a third party outside the organization
Internal or external audit inside the organization
Internal or external Audit with thorough test results

questionText: When an organization establishes a team for overseeing their security posture, who should be on the team?
explanation: Organizations will most likely establish a team that will be responsible for executing any assessment, testing, and auditing strategies. The team should consist of individuals who understand security assessment, testing, and auditing but should also include representatives from all other areas of the organization. Verifying and validating security are ongoing activities that never really stop. But security professionals should help guide an organization in terms of when a particular type of assessment or testing is best performed.

answerChoices.Text: Information security and physical security professionals
At least one person from every branch of the organization
All network, software, hardware and audit professionals
Chief executive officer, and all the divisional chiefs

questionText: Which of the following steps should be part of a vulnerability analysis?
explanation: The following steps should be part of a vulnerability analysis: Discuss the systems with the business owners and stakeholders. Examine the controls that are in place for the systems. Identify the vulnerabilities for the systems. A penetration test is generally not performed as part of a vulnerability analysis. A penetration test is usually performed after the vulnerability analysis is complete. The results of the vulnerability analysis are used to help determine the penetration tests that should be performed.

answerChoices.Text: Discuss the systems with the business owners and stakeholders.
Examine the controls that are in place for the systems.
Identify the vulnerabilities for the systems.
Statements a, b, and c only

questionText: Which of the following assessments and auditing processes are BEST preferred if an organization needs to comply with a standard or regulation or when accreditation or certification is involved?
explanation: Sometimes third-party assessment, testing, and auditing are performed by a party completely unrelated to the company and not previously engaged by it. This scenario often arises as a result of having to comply with some standard or regulation or when accreditation or certification is involved. Many certifying or regulating bodies may require engagement of a third party that has not had a previous relationship with the organization being assessed.

questionText: Which of the following vulnerability tests should be performed annually?
explanation: The listed tests should be performed at the following frequencies: Wardialing: Annually Network scanning: Quarterly Virus scanning: Weekly Vulnerability scanning: bimonthly Penetration testing: Annually Integrity checking: Monthly Wardriving: weekly
