explanation: The listed organizations and initiatives are defined as follows: WASC (Web Application Security Consortium): An organization that provides best practices for web-based applications along with a variety of resources, tools, and information that organizations can make use of in developing web applications. OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project): A group that monitors attacks, specifically web attacks. OWASP maintains a list of top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis. BSI (Build Security In): An initiative promoting a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes. ISO/IEC 27000: These standards provide guidance to organizations in integrating security into the development and maintenance of software applications.

questionText: Which of the following techniques uses bar charts?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Gantt chart: Bar charts that represent the progress of tasks and activities over a period of time. PERT: A method used for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project and the time required to complete each task. Delphi technique: Group members are asked to provide their opinion on a piece of paper in confidence. ACID Test: Ensures that each transaction has certain properties before it is committed.

questionText: Which software testing method is performed to debug the code instructions?
explanation: Unit testing is an internal testing performed to debug the code instructions.

questionText: Which of the following software attacks is used to access directories that are not supposed to be available from the web?
explanation: Cross site scripting attack: Arises from a vulnerability on a website that allows the attacker to inject malicious code into a web application Buffer overflow: An attack where an invalid amount of input is written to the buffer area SQL injection: When actual database commands are entered into the database input fields instead of the valid input Path traversal: Works by using the ./ characters, entered into the URL to traverse directories that are not supposed to be available from the web

questionText: In which of the following models is less time spent on the upfront analysis and more emphasis placed on learning from the process feedback and incorporating lessons learned in real time?
explanation: With the Agile model, less time is spent on upfront analysis and more emphasis is placed on learning from the process and incorporating lessons learned in real time. There is also more interaction with the customer throughout the process. In the Rapid Application Development (RAD) model, less time is spent upfront on design, while emphasis is placed on rapidly producing prototypes with the assumption that crucial knowledge can only be gained through trial and error. In contrast to the JAD model, the Cleanroom model strictly adheres to formal steps and a more structured method. It attempts to prevent errors and mistakes through extensive testing. In the modified Waterfall model, each phase in the development process is considered its own milestone in the project management process. Unlimited backward iteration (returning to earlier stages to address problems) is not allowed in this model.

questionText: What is the BEST POSSIBLE scenario while creating a computer program that has both cohesion and coupling?
explanation:
Cohesion

Cohesion is a term used to describe program organization. It is the degree to which elements of a module are related functionally. If it is limited to a small number or a single function, it is said to have high cohesion. High cohesion is good in that changes can be made to the model without affecting other modules. It also makes reusing the module easier. The highest cohesion is provided by limiting the scope of a module’s operation.

Coupling

Coupling describes how much interaction one module requires from another module to function the overall programming function. Low or loose coupling indicates that a module does not need much help from other modules, whereas high coupling indicates the opposite. If Module A needs to wait on results from messages it sent to three other modules before it can proceed, it is said to have high coupling. Low coupling, in other words, indicates how independent a class is from other classes. The best programming provides high cohesion and low coupling.

questionText: The Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) involves planning, which is a routine face-to-face event where all team members establish the objectives for the upcoming increment. This planning is known as:
explanation: Context analysis: Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) involves program increment (PI) planning, which is a routine, face-to-face event where all team members establish the objectives for the upcoming increment. Security objectives, such as compliance goals, risk mitigation strategies, and security feature development, can be integrated into PI planning to ensure they are prioritized and aligned with business objectives

questionText: In which stage of the change control process is the suggested change defined?
explanation: The steps in the change control process are as follows: Make a formal request: Define the suggested change. Analyze the request: Includes developing the implementation strategy, calculating the costs of the implementation, and reviewing the security implications of implementing the change. Record the change request: Document the results of the analysis. Submit the change request for approval: Getting approval of the actual change after all the work necessary to complete the change has been analyzed. Make changes: Changes are implemented and the version is updated in this step. Submit results to management: Results are reported to management for review.

questionText: Which of the following can MOSTLY help provide security for Application Programming Interfaces (API)?
explanation:
Guidelines for providing API security include

Use the same security controls for APIs as for any web application in the enterprise.

Use Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC).

Use encryption when passing static keys.

Use a framework or an existing library to implement security solutions for APIs.

Implement password encryption instead of single key-based authentication.

answerChoices.Text: Create digital encryption system (DES) hash code
Use pop-up blocking on the websites on server
Allow firewall signature monitoring on all APIs

questionText: Which technology provides digital signatures for software components?
explanation: Authenticode provides digital signatures for software components.

questionText: Which of the following is the process of taking away or removing characteristics from something to reduce it to a set of essential characteristics?
explanation: Abstraction usually results in named entities with a set of characteristics that help in their identification. However, unnecessary characteristics are hidden. Abstraction is related to both encapsulation and data hiding.

questionText: Which of the following test goes through the code line by line to identify vulnerabilities and known as white box testing of a software application?
explanation: Static Application Security Testing (SAST), also referred to as white-box testing, is the analysis of code at rest. This type of security testing goes through the code line-by-line to identify security vulnerabilities. Unlike SAST, DAST does not have access to the source code during security testing.

questionText: Which of the following is the capability of different objects with a common name to react to the same message or input with different output?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Polymorphism: The capability of different objects with a common name to react to the same message or input with different output. Cohesion: A term used to describe how many different tasks a module can carry out. If it is limited to a small number or a single function, it is said to have high cohesion. Coupling: Describes how much interaction one module requires from another module to do its job. Low or loose coupling indicates a module does not need much help from other modules, whereas high coupling indicates the opposite. Data structure: Refers to the logical relationship between elements of data. It describes the extent to which elements, methods of access, and processing alternatives are associated and the organization of data elements.

questionText: Which of the following software attacks results from an invalid amount of input?
explanation: Cross site scripting attack: Arises from a vulnerability on a website that allows the attacker to inject malicious code into a web application Buffer overflow: An attack where an invalid amount of input is written to the buffer area SQL injection: When actual database commands are entered into the database input fields instead of the valid input Path traversal: Works by using the ./ characters, entered into the URL to traverse directories that are not supposed to be available from the web

questionText: Which of the following is the dividing line between the trusted parts of the system and those that are untrusted?
explanation: The security perimeter is the dividing line between the trusted parts of the system and those that are untrusted. According to security design best practices, components that lie within this boundary (which means they lie within the TCB) should never permit untrusted components to access critical resources in an insecure manner.

questionText: What is the main aim of an attacker when they set up a botnet with several computers taking orders from his own computer, from where the attack instructions are given?
explanation: A bot is a type of malware that installs itself on large numbers of computers through infected emails, downloads from websites, Trojan horses, and shared media. After it’s installed, the bot can connect back to the hacker’s computer. After a connection is successfully established, the hacker’s server controls all the bots located on these machines. At a set time, the hacker might direct the bots to take some action, such as direct all the machines to send out spam messages, initiate a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, send phishing emails, or do any number of malicious acts. The collection of computers that act together is called a botnet, and the individual computers are called zombies. The attacker’s computer that manages the botnet is often referred to as the bot herder or bot master.

answerChoices.Text: Disable one computer in the network for Ransom
Look for ways to create denial-of-service (DDoS) attack
Create as many Zombie slaves for Trojan horse installation

questionText: Which of the following translates a program written in assembly language into machine code?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Interpreters: Translate one line of code at a time Compiler: Translates a section of code at a time Assembler: Takes a program written in assembly language as the input and translates it into the machine code Parallel test: Process of feeding test data into two systems, one altered system and another unaltered and comparing the results

questionText: Which of the following virus can infect more than one type of object and/or can infect a file or executable in more than one way?
explanation: Multipartite virus: Originally, this type of virus could infect both program files and boot sectors. This term now means that the virus can infect more than one type of object or can infect in more than one way.

questionText: Which of the following techniques is used to hide data?
explanation: Encapsulation is a popular technique that provides data hiding. Data hiding is the principle whereby data about a known entity is not accessible to certain processes or users.

questionText: Which of the following is NOT one of the four phases of acquiring software?
Which of the following describes how many different tasks a module can carry out?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Polymorphism: The ability of different objects with a common name to react to the same message or input with different output. Cohesion: A term used to describe how many different tasks a module can carry out. If it is limited to a small number or a single function, it is said to have high cohesion. Coupling: Describes how much interaction one module requires from other module to do its job. Low or loose coupling indicates a module does not need much help from other modules, whereas high coupling indicates the opposite. Data structure: Refers to the logical relationship between elements of data. It describes the extent to which elements, methods of access, and processing alternatives are associated and the organization of data elements.

questionText: When input to a application is configured in an unusual way what type POSSIBLE attack can it be called as?
explanation:
Buffer Overflow

As discussed in Chapter 5, a buffer is an area of memory where commands and data are placed until they can be processed by the CPU. A buffer overflow occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or, in some cases, execute commands on the machine if the hackers can locate an area where commands can be executed. Not all attacks are designed to execute commands. Some just lock up the computer and are used as DoS attacks.

A packet containing a long string of no-operation instructions (NOPs) followed by a command is usually indicative of a type of buffer overflow attack called an NOP slide. The purpose is to get the CPU to locate where a command can be executed. 

In many cases, the key to preventing buffer overflow attacks is input validation. This method requires that any input be checked for format and length before it is used. Buffer overflows and boundary errors (when input exceeds the boundaries allotted for the input) are considered to be a family of error conditions called input validation errors.

Malformed input is the category in which all buffer overflow attacks fit. Malformed input is any attack in which the input is configured in an unusual way.

questionText: Which of the following translates one line of code at a time?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Interpreters: Translate one line of code at a time Compiler: Translates a section of code at a time Assembler: Takes a program written in assembly language as the input and translates it into the machine code Parallel test: Process of feeding test data into two systems, one altered system and another unaltered and comparing the results

questionText: Which language type delivers instructions directly to the processor?
explanation: Machine languages deliver instructions directly to the processor. This was the only type of programming done in the 1950s and uses basic binary instructions, using no complier or interpreter. (These programs convert higher language types to a form that can be executed by the processor.)

questionText: When sharing objects, a user includes an Excel worksheet in a Microsoft Word document. This is known as:
explanation: Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) is a method for sharing objects on a local computer that uses COM (Component Object Model) as its foundation. In fact, OLE is sometimes described as the predecessor of COM. It allows objects to be embedded in documents (spreadsheets, graphics, and so on). The term linking refers to the relationship between one program and another, and the term embedding refers to the placement of data into a foreign program or document. One example of OLE is including an Excel worksheet in a Microsoft Word document.

questionText: Which attack consists of -interrupting a task and changing something to affect the result while the tasks occur in the correct order?
explanation: The listed attacks are described as follows: Time-of-check/time-of-use (TOC/TOU) attack: Interrupting a task and changing something to affect the result while the tasks occur in the correct order. Race condition: Causing processes to execute in a different order to affect the result. Emanations capturing: Eavesdropping on wave frequencies to capture traffic. Maintenance hooks: Backdoors in applications that are designed by the application developers to perform maintenance tasks, which can enable code to be executed without the usual security checks. Buffer overflow: Transmitting too much data to an application or operating system.

questionText: Which phase of the system development life cycle involves consideration of security requirements?
explanation: The listed phases are defined as follows: Project initiation phase: Involves consideration of security requirements, such as encryption Acquire/develop phase: Includes coding and scripting of software applications System design specification phase: Focuses on providing details on which kind of security mechanism will be a part of the software product Implementation stage: Involves use of an application on production systems in the organization

questionText: Which of the following is considered software when security is focused on protection of the computer software?
explanation:
Software development security covers all the security issues and controls that security professionals must understand when dealing with commercial or in-house-developed software. They should understand the software development lifecycle and be able to assess software security effectiveness and the impact of software.
Software is at the heart of all functionality in computer systems. Various types of software, including operating systems, applications, and utilities, work together to deliver instructions from a human to hardware. All these instructions are created with the intent of making some operation possible.
When software is written and developed, the focus can be placed on its functionality and ease of use or on its security. In many cases, the two goals might work at cross purposes. Giving inadequate attention to the security of a piece of software results in software that can introduce security issues to both the application and the systems on which it is run.

answerChoices.Text: All operating system, applications, and utilities written in any language
Written in high level language for front end users and website programming
High level language, middle level and low level language syntax and semantics
Programs created or bought that follow Systems life cycle, software lifecycle

questionText: What is the BIGGEST emphasis of an agile software development model?
explanation: The Agile model puts more emphasis on continuous feedback and cross-functional teamwork. This model attempts to be nimble enough to react to situations that arise during development. Less time is spent on the upfront analysis and more emphasis is placed on learning from the process and incorporating lessons learned in real time. There is also regular and active interaction with the customer throughout the process.

answerChoices.Text: Customer feedback is not required till final product
Lessons learned is not important as model is dynamic
Maximum number of hours are spent on upfront analysis

questionText: In what phase of the software development life cycle (SDLC), does a programmer start writing the actual code for an application?
explanation: The Develop phase involves writing the code or instructions that make the software work. The emphasis of this phase is strict adherence to secure coding practices.

questionText: Which of the following statements correctly describes polymorphism as used in object oriented programming?
explanation: In an object-oriented system, polymorphism denotes objects of many different classes that are related by some common superclass; thus, any object denoted by this name can respond to some common set of operations in a different way. Polymorphism is the ability of different objects with a common name to react to the same message or input and produce a different output. For example, three objects can be created to receive the string “Toyota Corolla” as input. One object’s output might be “subcompact”, another’s might be “uses regular fuel”, and another’s might be “costs 18,000”. In some cases, these differences derive from the fact that the objects have inherited different characteristics from their parent classes

answerChoices.Text: Every subject must have the same name and produce the exact same output
Different objects with a common name and same input produce a different output
All objects have a unique name and produce distinctly different output
Different subjects with a common name and same output receive a different input

questionText: Which software development model is MOST appropriate where high quality is a MUST, application is mission critical and solution needs strict certification process?
explanation: The Cleanroom model strictly adheres to formal steps and a more structured method. It attempts to prevent errors and mistakes through extensive testing. This method works well in situations where high quality is a must, the application is mission critical, or the solution must undergo a strict certification process.

questionText: What is the process known as when it provides clear and logical steps to ensure that a system or software conforms to the intended functionality with an acceptable level of security?
explanation: When an organization defines new functionality that must be provided either to its customers or internally, it must create systems to deliver that functionality. Many decisions have to be made, and a logical process should be followed in making those decisions. This process is called the System Development Lifecycle (SDLC) . Rather than being a haphazard approach, the SDLC provides clear and logical steps to follow to ensure that the system that emerges at the end of the development process provides the intended functionality with an acceptable level of security.

questionText: What is the main aim of verification testing in software?
explanation:
In the Test/Validate phase, several types of testing should occur, including ways to identify both functional errors and security issues. The auditing method that assesses the extent of the system testing and identifies specific program logic that has not been tested is called the test data method. This method tests not only expected or valid input but also invalid and unexpected values to assess the behavior of the software in both instances. An active attempt should be made to attack the software, including attempts at buffer overflows and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Some goals of testing performed at this time are
Verification testing: Determines whether the original design specifications have been met.
Validation testing: Takes a higher-level view and determines whether the original purpose of the software has been achieved.

answerChoices.Text: To check if the software meets the original design specifications
To make sure that the purpose of software is achieved
To verify that the software is functioning in all stages of life cycle
To verify that the software functions required security

questionText: Which of the following is a process used to prevent data inference violations?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Database locks: Prevents another user from accessing the record at the same time to prevent edits until the first user is finished Polyinstantiation: Is a process used to prevent data inference violations Aggregation: A database security concern that arises when a user does not have complete access to sensitive data but can access portions of it. Spiral: Is a model based on analyzing the risk, building prototypes, and simulating the application tasks during the various phases of the development cycle

questionText: A programmer creating an application is told to use a pre-defined protection scheme with a limited number of rules under which only access is permitted. This access is known as:
explanation:
Implement Default Deny

Security professionals should ensure that, by default, access is denied and the protection scheme identifies conditions under which access is permitted.

questionText: Which of the following is a model based on analyzing the risk, building prototypes, and simulating the application tasks?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Database locks: Prevents another user from accessing the record at the same time to prevent edits until the first user is finished Polyinstantiation: Is a process used to prevent data inference violations Aggregation: A database security concern that arises when a user does not have complete access to sensitive data but can access portions of it. Spiral: Is a model based on analyzing the risk, building prototypes, and simulating the application tasks during the various phases of the development cycle

questionText: Which of the following viruses is the most difficult to detect and clean?
explanation:
A rootkit is a set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after managing to gain access and elevating privileges to administrator. It gets its name from the root account, the most powerful account in UNIX-based operating systems. The rootkit tools might include a backdoor for the hacker to access. This is one of the hardest types of malware to remove, and in many cases only a reformat of the hard drive will completely remove it.

The following are some of the actions a rootkit can take:


	Install a backdoor.
	Remove all entries from the security log (log scrubbing).
	Replace default tools with compromised versions (Trojan’ed programs).
	Make malicious kernel changes.

questionText: In Object Oriented Programming (OOP), What are the characteristics of each class called?
explanation: In classic software development, data is input into a program, the program manages the data from beginning to end, and a result is returned. Object-oriented programming (OOP) supplies the same functionality, but it is more efficiently introduced through different techniques. In OOP, objects are organized in a hierarchy of classes with characteristics called attributes attached to each class. OOP emphasizes the employment of objects and methods rather than types or transformations.

questionText: Which attack uses backdoors in applications that are designed by the application developers to perform maintenance tasks?
explanation: The listed attacks are described as follows: Time-of-check/time-of-use (TOC/TOU) attack: Interrupting a task and changing something to affect the result while the tasks occur in the correct order. Race condition: Causing processes to execute in a different order to affect the result. Emanations capturing: Eavesdropping on wave frequencies to capture traffic. Maintenance hooks: Backdoors in applications that are designed by the application developers to perform maintenance tasks, which can enable code to be executed without the usual security checks. Buffer overflow: Transmitting too much data to an application or operating system.

questionText: Which of the following components can be considered as trusted in a computer operating on an open network?
explanation:
Developers should follow secure coding practices. Earlier in this chapter, we covered software development security best practices. In addition to those best practices, developers should keep in mind the secure coding best practices covered in the following sections.

Validate Input

Developers should be sure to validate any input into an application from all untrusted data sources. Proper input validation can eliminate the vast majority of software vulnerabilities. Most external data sources, including command-line arguments, network interfaces, environmental variables, and user-controlled files, should be considered untrusted.

questionText: In which phase of the system development life cycle is the solution introduced to the production environment?
explanation: The listed phases are defined as follows: Project initiation phase: Involves consideration of security requirements, such as encryption Acquire/develop phase: Includes coding and scripting of software applications System design specification phase: Focuses on providing details on which kind of security mechanism will be a part of the software product Implementation stage: Involves use of an application on production systems in the organization

questionText: Which of the following organizations or initiatives monitor attacks, specifically web attacks?
explanation: The listed organizations and initiatives are defined as follows: WASC (Web Application Security Consortium): An organization that provides best practices for web-based applications along with a variety of resources, tools, and information that organizations can make use of in developing web applications. OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project): A group that monitors attacks, specifically web attacks. OWASP maintains a list of top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis. BSI (Build Security In): An initiative promoting a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes. ISO/IEC 27000: These standards provide guidance to organizations in integrating security into the development and maintenance of software applications.

questionText: Which of the following is a comprehensive set of guidelines that addresses all phases of the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)?
explanation: The Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) is a comprehensive set of guidelines that addresses all phases of the Software Development Life Cycle. It describes a series of stages or maturity levels that a development process can advance through as it goes from the ad hoc (Build and Fix) model to one that incorporates a budgeted plan for continuous improvement.

questionText: Proper implementation of security levels is a countermeasure for which attack type?
explanation: The listed attacks can be mitigated with the following countermeasures: TOC/TOU: Make critical sets of instructions atomic. Inference: Polyinstantiation, which is the development of a detailed version of an object from another object using different values in the new object. Buffer overflow: Input validation. Maintenance hooks: Code reviews. Data contamination: Proper implementation of security levels.

questionText: In object oriented programming what is it called, if the elements of a module are limited to a single function and provide limited scope for the module?
explanation: Cohesion is a term used to describe program organization. It is the degree to which elements of a module are related functionally. If it is limited to a small number or a single function, it is said to have high cohesion. High cohesion is good in that changes can be made to the model without affecting other modules. It also makes reusing the module easier. The highest cohesion is provided by limiting the scope of a module’s operation.

questionText: In which of the following stages of the Software Development Life Cycle is the software actually coded?
explanation: The Develop stage involves writing the code or instructions that make the software work. The emphasis of this phase is strict adherence to secure coding practice.

questionText: Which of the following techniques ensures that each transaction has certain properties before it is committed?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Gantt chart: Bar charts that represent the progress of tasks and activities over a period of time. PERT: A method used for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project and the time required to complete each task. Delphi technique: Group members are asked to provide their opinion on a piece of paper in confidence. ACID Test: Ensures that each transaction has certain properties before it is committed.

questionText: When an application was developed by a third party for an organization, a service-level agreement (SLA) MUST have a clause to include:
explanation: Service-level agreement: If an app was developed for an organization by a third party, a service-level agreement (SLA) may have been included as part of the vendor contract. This contract should require the app to be compatible with the organization’s security policy.

answerChoices.Text: Supplying user guides in more than one language
Meeting authorization plans and answer questions
Third party’s ability to respond round the clock

questionText: Which of the following security testing combines the elements of static and dynamic application security methodologies and might operate from within the application or runtime environment, providing real-time feedback on security issues?
explanation: Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) is a modern approach to application security testing that combines elements of SAST and DAST methodologies to identify vulnerabilities in web applications and services. IAST operates from within the application or runtime environment, providing real-time feedback on security issues as the application is used or tested during the development and testing phases.

answerChoices.Text: Security Testing of Applications at Runtime (STAR)

questionText: Which of the following is a piece of software installed by a hacker that allows them to return later without authentication?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Rootkit: A set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after he has managed to gain access and elevate his privileges to administrator. Buffer Overflow: Occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or in some cases execute commands on the machine if he can locate an area where commands can be executed. Privilege Escalation: The process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow a user to receive privileges to which they are not entitled. Backdoor: A piece of software installed by a hacker that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process.

questionText: Which of the following is the BEST countermeasure to mitigate the dangers of maintenance hooks?
explanation: The best solution is for the vendor to remove all maintenance hooks before the product goes into production.

answerChoices.Text: Record any attempt to access the system using one of these hooks.
Remove all maintenance hooks before the product goes into production.
Encrypt all sensitive information contained in the system.
Implement auditing to supplement the IDS.

questionText: The protected environment a java virtual machine executes an applet is called as:
Which phase of the system development life cycle focuses on providing details on which kind of security mechanism is included?
explanation: The listed phases are defined as follows: Project initiation phase: Involves consideration of security requirements, such as encryption Acquire/develop phase: Includes coding and scripting of software applications System design specification phase: Focuses on providing details on which kind of security mechanism will be a part of the software product Implementation stage: Involves use of an application on production systems in the organization

questionText: Which phase of the system development life cycle includes coding and scripting?
explanation: The listed phases are defined as follows: Project initiation phase: Involves consideration of security requirements, such as encryption Acquire/develop phase: Includes coding and scripting of software applications System design specification phase: Focuses on providing details on which kind of security mechanism will be a part of the software product Implementation stage: Involves use of an application on production systems in the organization

questionText: Which of the following describes a software module that is easier to update?
explanation: The listed descriptions are defined as follows: Low coupling: Module performs its job without using other modules. High coupling: Module must interact with other modules to perform its job. High cohesion: Module is easier to update and does not affect other modules. Low cohesion: Module carries out many tasks, making it harder to maintain and reuse.

questionText: Which of the following are the kinds of viruses in software?
explanation:
Some of the malware that security professionals need to understand includes the following:

Virus

Boot sector virus

Parasitic virus

Stealth virus

Polymorphic virus

Macro virus

Multipartite virus

answerChoices.Text: Logic bomb, worm, botnet and ransomware
Boot sector, kay logger, and trojan horse
Rootkit, payload, micro and SQL injection

questionText: Which software development model makes changes several times a day, week or month and deploys changed code on production as the bugs are fixed?
explanation: Continuous integration (CI) refers to the process of frequently integrating code changes and updates, provided by the development team, during software development. These changes may occur several times a day. Automated testing of the code is built into the CI process. Continuous delivery (CD) refers to the frequent transfer of changes to production. These changes may include bug fixes or configuration changes. During the CD process, code can be deployed at any time, provided that automated test cases were successful.

answerChoices.Text: Change, Test and deploy as often as necessary

questionText: What is the software installed by hackers known as, that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process and bypass access control measures?
explanation: A backdoor is a piece of software installed by hackers, using one of the delivery mechanisms  that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process. A backdoor normally bypasses access control measures. Some commercial applications inadvertently include backdoors because programmers forget to remove them before release to market.

questionText: Which of the following ensures that the customer (either internal or external) is satisfied with the functionality of the software?
explanation: Acceptance testing ensures that the customer (either internal or external) is satisfied with the functionality of the software. Integration testing assesses how the modules work together and determines whether functional and security specifications have been met. Regression testing takes places after changes are made to the code to ensure that the changes have reduced neither functionality nor security. Accreditation is the formal acceptance of the adequacy of a system's overall security by management.

questionText: Which of the following standardized interfaces and components called service brokers to facilitate communication among web-based applications?
explanation: A newer approach to providing a distributed computing model is the service-oriented architecture (SOA). It operates on the theory of providing web-based communication functionality without each application requiring redundant code to be written per application. It uses standardized interfaces and components called service brokers to facilitate communication among web-based applications.

questionText: What virus makes copies of itself and makes changes to those copies to avoid detection from antivirus software?
explanation: Polymorphic virus: This type of virus makes copies of itself, and then makes changes to those copies. It does so in hopes of avoiding detection from antivirus software.

questionText: Which of the following initiatives was developed by the Department of Homeland Security?
explanation: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is involved in promoting software security best practices. The Build Security In (BSI) initiative promotes a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes.

questionText: What are the five steps of the IDEAL software development model?
explanation:
The IDEAL model was developed by the Software Engineering Institute to provide guidance on software development. Its name is an acronym that stands for the five phases:


	Initiate: Outline the business reasons behind the change, build support for the initiative, and implement the infrastructure needed.
	Diagnose: Analyze the current organizational state and make change recommendations.
	Establish: Take the recommendations from the previous phase and use them to develop an action plan.
	Act: Develop, test, refine, and implement the solutions according to the action plan from the previous phase.
	Learn: Use the quality improvement process to determine whether goals have been met and develop new actions based on the analysis.

answerChoices.Text: Initiate, Develop, Enable, Apply and Learn
Institute, Deliver, Empower, Affect and Link
Initiate, Diagnose, Establish, Act and Learn
Interact, Design, Entrust, Activate and Lock

questionText: When harassed by a supervisor, a programmer writes a piece of code into the software in such a way that the software will fail to run on the first day or every month at 9 AM. What kind of malware can this be BEST termed as?
explanation: A logic bomb is a type of malware that executes when a particular event takes place. For example, that event could be a time of day or a specific date, or it could be the first time you open notepad.exe. Some logic bombs execute when digital forensics is being conducted, and in that case the bomb might delete all digital evidence.

questionText: Which of the following virus propagates by itself without user intervention or assistance?
explanation: A worm is a type of malware that can spread without the assistance of the user. It is a small program that, like a virus, is used to deliver a payload. One way to help mitigate the effects of worms is to place limits on sharing, writing, and executing programs.

questionText: Which attack interrupts and changes a process to affect the result while the tasks continue to occur in the correct order?
explanation: The listed attacks are described as follows: Time-of-check/time-of-use (TOC/TOU) attack: Interrupting a task and changing something to affect the result while the tasks occur in the correct order. Race condition: Causing processes to execute in a different order to affect the result. Emanations capturing: Eavesdropping on wave frequencies to capture traffic. Maintenance hooks: Backdoors in applications that are designed by the application developers to perform maintenance tasks, which can enable code to be executed without the usual security checks. Buffer overflow: Transmitting too much data to an application or operating system.

questionText: Which software development model follows a rigid approach of going through a series of sequential steps without going back to the previous steps?
explanation:
Waterfall Model

The original Waterfall model breaks the development process into distinct phases. Although this model uses somewhat of a rigid approach, the basic process is as a sequential series of steps that are followed without going back to earlier steps.

questionText: Which of the following correctly defines the line between the trusted parts of the system and the parts that are untrusted?
explanation:
In 1972, the U.S. government commissioned the Computer Security Technology Planning Study to outline the basic and foundational security requirements of systems purchased by the government. This study eventually led to the Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria, or Orange Book (discussed in more detail in Chapter 3, “Security Architecture and Engineering”). This section defines some of the core tenets in the Orange Book:


	Trusted computer base (TCB): The TCB comprises the components (hardware, firmware, and/or software) that are trusted to enforce the security policy of the system and that, if compromised, jeopardize the security properties of the entire system. The reference monitor is a primary component of the TCB. This term is derived from the Orange Book. All changes to the TCB should be audited and controlled, which is an example of a configuration management control.
	Security perimeter: This is the dividing line between the trusted parts of the system and the parts that are untrusted. According to security design best practices, components that lie within this boundary (which means they lie within the TCB) should never permit untrusted components to access critical resources in an insecure manner.
	Reference monitor: A reference monitor is a system component that enforces access controls on an object. It is an access control concept that refers to an abstract machine that mediates all accesses to objects by subjects. It was introduced for circumventing difficulties in classic approaches to computer security by limiting damages produced by malicious programs. The security risk created by a covert channel is that it bypasses the reference monitor functions. The reference monitor should exhibit isolation, completeness, and verifiability.

questionText: Which of the following software development risk analysis and mitigation strategy guidelines should security professionals follow? (Choose all that apply.)

MultipleChoice.Text: ltpgt-openIntegrate risk analysis and mitigation in the Software Development Life Cycle.ltpgt-close
ltpgt-openUse qualitative, quantitative, and hybrid risk analysis approaches based on standardized risk analysis methods.ltpgt-close
ltpgt-openTrack and manage weaknesses that are discovered throughout risk assessment, change management, and continuous monitoring.ltpgt-close
ltpgt-openEncapsulate data to make it easier to apply the appropriate policies to objects.ltpgt-close

questionText: What kind of malware spreads without the assistance of an end user?
explanation: A worm is a type of malware that can spread without the assistance of the user. It is a small program that, like a virus, is used to deliver a payload. One way to help mitigate the effects of worms is to place limits on sharing, writing, and executing programs.

questionText: Which attack causes processes to execute in a different order to affect the result?
explanation: The listed attacks are described as follows: Time-of-check/time-of-use (TOC/TOU) attack: Interrupting a task and changing something to affect the result while the tasks occur in the correct order. Race condition: Causing processes to execute in a different order to affect the result. Emanations capturing: Eavesdropping on wave frequencies to capture traffic. Maintenance hooks: Backdoors in applications that are designed by the application developers to perform maintenance tasks, which can enable code to be executed without the usual security checks. Buffer overflow: Transmitting too much data to an application or operating system.

questionText: Which of the following is a set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after he has managed to gain access?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Rootkit: A set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after he has managed to gain access and elevate his privileges to administrator. Buffer Overflow: Occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or in some cases execute commands on the machine if he can locate an area in which commands can be executed. Privilege Escalation: The process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow a user to receive privileges to which they are not entitled. Backdoor: A piece of software installed by a hacker that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process.

questionText: Which of the following languages uses symbols or mnemonics to represent sections of complicated binary code?
explanation: Considered to be “one step above” machine languages, assembly languages use symbols or mnemonics to represent sections of complicated binary code. Consequently, these languages use an assembler to convert the code to machine level. Although this tool greatly simplifies and shortens the code, it still requires extensive knowledge of the computer’s architecture. It also means that any code written in these languages will be hardware specific.

questionText: When each module of a software is tested to see if each meets the requirements correctly and validates properly, the testing is known as:
explanation: Software is typically developed in pieces or modules of code that are later assembled to produce the final product. Each module should be tested separately, in a procedure called unit testing. Having development staff carry out this testing is critical, but using a different group of engineers than the ones who wrote the code can ensure that an impartial process occurs. This is a good example of the concept of separation of duties.

questionText: Which of the following describes a software module that performs its job without using other modules?
explanation: The listed descriptions are defined as follows: Low coupling: Module performs its job without using other modules. High coupling: Module must interact with other modules to perform its job. High cohesion: Module is easier to update and does not affect other modules. Low cohesion: Module carries out many tasks, making it harder to maintain and reuse.

questionText: Which of the following is a database security concern that arises when a user does not have complete access to sensitive data but can access portions of it?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Database locks: Prevents another user from accessing the record at the same time to prevent edits until the first user is finished Polyinstantiation: Is a process used to prevent data inference violations Aggregation: A database security concern that arises when a user does not have complete access to sensitive data but can access portions of it. Spiral: Is a model based on analyzing the risk, building prototypes, and simulating the application tasks during the various phases of the development cycle

questionText: Which of the following tests code at rest and is known as white-box testing?
explanation:
Application testing is a critical part of software development, with the goal of identifying security vulnerabilities. As you have just learned from DevSecOps, security testing should be integrated in every phase of the development lifecycle, which means that application security testing should begin early in application development.

Static Application Security Testing (SAST), also referred to as white-box testing, is the analysis of code at rest. This type of security testing goes through the code line-by-line to identify security vulnerabilities. Unlike SAST, DAST does not have access to the source code during security testing.

questionText: Which of the following occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Rootkit: A set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after he has managed to gain access and elevate his privileges to administrator. Buffer Overflow: Occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or in some cases execute commands on the machine if he can locate an area in which commands can be executed. Privilege Escalation: The process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow a user to receive privileges to which they are not entitled. Backdoor: A piece of software installed by a hacker that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process.

questionText: Which of the following techniques is a method used for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project and the time required to complete each task without using a bar chart?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Gantt chart- bar charts that represent the progress of tasks and activities over a period of time PERT- a method used for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project and the time required to complete each task Delphi technique -Group members are asked to provide their opinion on a piece of paper in confidence ACID Test- ensures that each transaction has certain properties before it is committed
comments: 4/29/25 - query to Au

questionText: Which of the following software development models is MOST suitable when a customer has MINIMUM requirements for a software application?
explanation: MPM is a prototyping method that is used with minimal requirements. The client provides feedback, and then a fully functioning prototype is developed and used as the basis for the final product.

questionText: Which of the following can be used to prevent low-level objects from gaining or getting access to information from a higher security level?
explanation: Polyinstantiation prevents low-level objects from gaining information from a higher security level. Objects may act differently depending on the data they contain. For this reason, it may be difficult to determine whether inherited security properties are valid. Polyinstantiation prevents inference database attacks

questionText: Which of the following software model puts emphasis on feedback and cross functional teamwork?
explanation:
In many software development, the focus is more on following procedural steps than on reacting to changes quickly and increasing efficiency. The Agile model puts more emphasis on continuous feedback and cross-functional teamwork.

This model attempts to be nimble enough to react to situations that arise during development. Less time is spent on the upfront analysis and more emphasis is placed on learning from the process and incorporating lessons learned in real time. There is also regular and active interaction with the customer throughout the process. Figure 8-5 compares the Agile model with the Waterfall model.

questionText: Which of the following knowledge is required for a security professional to assess commercial off the shelf (COTS) software?
explanation:
For security professionals, assessing the security impact of acquired software requires:


	Due Diligence and Risk Assessment: Conducting thorough due diligence to understand the security posture and practices of the software or service provider. This includes risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities and impacts on the organization’s security posture.
	Compliance and Regulation Review: Ensuring that the software or services comply with applicable laws, regulations, and industry standards, especially those related to data protection and privacy.
	Vendor Management: Establishing strong vendor management practices, including setting clear security requirements and regularly reviewing vendors' adherence to these requirements.
	Security Integration and Monitoring: Integrating acquired software into the organization’s broader security framework, including implementing necessary controls and continuously monitoring for new vulnerabilities or security issues.

questionText: In which stage of the change control process is the change implemented?
explanation: The steps in the change control process are as follows: Make a formal request: Define the suggested change. Analyze the request: Includes developing the implementation strategy, calculating the costs of the implementation, and reviewing the security implications of implementing the change. Record the change request: Document the results of the analysis. Submit the change request for approval: Getting approval of the actual change after all the work necessary to complete the change has been analyzed. Make changes: Changes are implemented and the version is updated in this step. Submit results to management: Results are reported to management for review.

questionText: In which stage of the change control process is approval granted?
explanation: The steps in the change control process are as follows: Make a formal request: Define the suggested change. Analyze the request: Includes developing the implementation strategy, calculating the costs of the implementation, and reviewing the security implications of implementing the change. Record the change request: Document the results of the analysis. Submit the change request for approval: Getting approval of the actual change after all the work necessary to complete the change has been analyzed. Make changes: Changes are implemented and the version is updated in this step. Submit results to management: Results are reported to management for review.

questionText: When an attacker sets up a botnet with several computers taking orders from his own computer, his own computer from where the attack instructions are given, is known as:
explanation: A bot is a type of malware that installs itself on large numbers of computers through infected emails, downloads from websites, Trojan horses, and shared media. After it’s installed, the bot can connect back to the hacker’s computer. After a connection is successfully established, the hacker’s server controls all the bots located on these machines. At a set time, the hacker might direct the bots to take some action, such as direct all the machines to send out spam messages, initiate a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, send phishing emails, or do any number of malicious acts. The collection of computers that act together is called a botnet, and the individual computers are called zombies. The attacker’s computer that manages the botnet is often referred to as the bot herder or bot master.

questionText: What is the MOST important idea behind the concept of defense in depth?
explanation:
Adhere to the Principle of Least Privilege, and Practice Defense in Depth

Every software action should execute with the least set of privileges necessary to complete the job. Any elevated permission should be granted for a minimum period of time necessary. This approach reduces the chance that an attacker can execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.

Implement multiple defensive strategies, also known as defense in depth. Doing so ensures that if one layer of defense turns out to be inadequate, another layer of defense can prevent a security flaw from becoming an exploitable vulnerability and/or limit the consequences of a successful exploit.

answerChoices.Text: A least privileged user cannot elevate their privileges vertically or horizontally
Several mechanisms help prevent a security flaw from becoming a bad vulnerability
Creating a new baseline of a system with completed changes as quickly as possible
Layers of defense can check vulnerabilities but may not actually prevent an attack

questionText: Which of the following organizations or initiatives provide guidance to organizations in integrating security into the development and maintenance of software applications?
explanation: The listed organizations and initiatives are defined as follows: WASC (Web Application Security Consortium): An organization that provides best practices for web-based applications along with a variety of resources, tools, and information that organizations can make use of in developing web applications. OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project): A group that monitors attacks, specifically web attacks. OWASP maintains a list of top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis. BSI (Build Security In): An initiative promotes a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes. ISO/IEC 27000: These standards provide guidance to organizations in integrating security into the development and maintenance of software applications.

questionText: The process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow users to access computer resources they should not, is known as:
explanation: Privilege escalation is the process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow users to receive privileges to which they are not entitled. These privileges can be used to delete files, view private information, or install unwanted programs such as viruses.

questionText: Which of the following is a Microsoft technology?
explanation: ActiveX is a Microsoft technology that uses object-oriented programming (OOP) and is based on the COM and DCOM.

questionText: Which secure coding practice is suitable while developing an in-house application?
explanation:
Adhere to the Principle of Least Privilege, and Practice Defense in Depth

Every software action should execute with the least set of privileges necessary to complete the job. Any elevated permission should be granted for a minimum period of time necessary. This approach reduces the chance that an attacker can execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.

Implement multiple defensive strategies, also known as defense in depth. Doing so ensures that if one layer of defense turns out to be inadequate, another layer of defense can prevent a security flaw from becoming an exploitable vulnerability and/or limit the consequences of a successful exploit.

answerChoices.Text: Only external data needs to be validated but not the in-house data
All actions in code should execute with least set of privileges provided
Do not allow any access to users on the database tables but only views
Code written must be verified by system administrators before deploying

questionText: Many decisions have to be made when an organization aims to provide a new functionality to its customers. What is the logical process known as, for making decisions in creating systems to deliver the functionality?
explanation:
The System Development Life Cycle includes the following phases:

1.         Initiate

2.         Acquire/Develop

3.         Implement

4.         Operate/Maintain

5.         Dispose

When an organization defines new functionality that must be provided either to its customers or internally, it must create systems to deliver that functionality. Many decisions have to be made, and a logical process should be followed in making those decisions. This process is called the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC).

questionText: Which tool is MOST suitable to identify and evaluate security, licensing, and operational risks associated with open-source and third-party components in a software project?
explanation: Software Composition Analysis (SCA) is a critical tool to identify and evaluate the security, licensing, and operational risks associated with open-source and third-party components in a software project. As modern software development increasingly relies on open-source components and third-party libraries to speed up development and leverage existing solutions, it becomes essential to manage the risks associated with these components.

questionText: What is it known as, when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process?
explanation:
Security Weaknesses and Vulnerabilities at the Source Code Level

Many security issues with software have their roots in poor development practices. A number of threats can be minimized by following certain established software coding principles. Here, we discuss source code issues, along with some guidelines for secure development processes.

Buffer Overflow

A buffer is an area of memory where commands and data are placed until they can be processed by the CPU. A buffer overflow occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process.

questionText: Which of the following organization/group that monitors web attacks specifically the top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis?
explanation:
To support the goal of ensuring that software is soundly developed with regard to both functionality and security, a number of organizations have attempted to assemble a set of software development best practices. First, we look at some of those organizations, and then we look at a number of their most important recommendations.

WASC

The Web Application Security Consortium (WASC) is an organization that provides best practices for web-based applications along with a variety of resources, tools, and information that organizations can make use of in developing web applications.
One of the functions undertaken by WASC is continual monitoring of attacks leading to the development and maintenance of an up-to-date list of top attack methods that are currently known. This list can aid in ensuring that organizations not only are aware of the latest attack methods and how widespread these attacks are but also can make the proper precautions and care to their web applications to mitigate these attack types.

OWASP

The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) is another group that monitors attacks, specifically web attacks. OWASP maintains a list of top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis. This group also holds regular meetings at chapters throughout the world, providing resources and tools including testing procedures, code review steps, and development guidelines.

answerChoices.Text: Internet Security Tracking for Top Ten (ISTTT)

questionText: Which term describes how many different tasks a module can carry out?
explanation: Cohesion describes how many different tasks a module can carry out. If a module is limited to a small number or a single function, it is said to have high cohesion. Coupling describes how much interaction one module requires from another module to do its job. Low or loose coupling indicates that a module does not need much help from other modules, whereas high coupling indicates the opposite.

questionText: Which of the following is the last step in the System Development Life Cycle?
explanation:
The five steps in the System Development Life Cycle are as follows: 

1.   Initiate
2.   Acquire/Develop
3.   Implement
4.   Operate/Maintain
5.   Dispose

questionText: Which of the following organizations or initiatives promotes a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes?
explanation: The listed organizations and initiatives are defined as follows: WASC (Web Application Security Consortium): An organization that provides best practices for web-based applications along with a variety of resources, tools, and information that organizations can make use of in developing web applications. OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project ): A group that monitors attacks, specifically web attacks. OWASP maintains a list of top 10 attacks on an ongoing basis. BSI (Build Security In): An initiative promotes a process-agnostic approach that makes security recommendations with regard to architectures, testing methods, code reviews, and management processes. ISO/IEC 27000: These standards provide guidance to organizations in integrating security into the development and maintenance of software applications.

questionText: In which stage of the change control process are the security implications reviewed?
explanation: The steps in the change control process are as follows: Make a formal request: Define the suggested change. Analyze the request: Includes developing the implementation strategy, calculating the costs of the implementation, and reviewing the security implications of implementing the change. Record the change request: Document the results of the analysis. Submit the change request for approval: Getting approval of the actual change after all the work necessary to complete the change has been analyzed. Make changes: Changes are implemented and the version is updated in this step. Submit results to management: Results are reported to management for review.

questionText: Which type of software testing confirms the validity of the design specifications?
explanation: The listed testing types have the following characteristics: Regression testing: Tests the functionality, performance, and protection of an application after a change takes place Unit testing: Initial testing that occurs to ensure that individual application components are validated to data structure, logic, and boundary conditions Integration testing: Verifies that application components work together as outlined in the design specifications Acceptance testing: Ensures that the code meets customer requirements

questionText: What is the process BEST known as, when a software is evaluated for its security effectiveness per customer’s needs?
Which of the following is the process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow a user to perform functions for which they are not authorized?
explanation: The listed terms are defined as follows: Rootkit: A set of tools that a hacker can use on a computer after he has managed to gain access and elevate his privileges to administrator. Buffer Overflow: Occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or in some cases execute commands on the machine if he can locate an area where commands can be executed. Privilege Escalation: The process of exploiting a bug or weakness in an operating system to allow a user to receive privileges to which they are not entitled. Backdoor: A piece of software installed by a hacker that allows them to return later and connect to the computer without going through the normal authentication process.

questionText: What does the vetting process involve according to the “NIST SP 800-163 standard – Vetting the security of mobile applications?”
explanation: To provide software assurance for apps, organizations should develop security requirements that specify, for example, how data used by an app should be secured, the environment in which an app will be deployed, and the acceptable level of risk for an app. To help ensure that an app conforms to such requirements, a process for evaluating the security of apps should be performed. This process is referred to as an app vetting process. An app vetting process is a sequence of activities that aims to determine whether an app conforms to the organization’s security requirements. This process is performed on an app after the app has been developed and released for distribution but prior to its deployment on an organization’s mobile device. Thus, an app vetting process is distinguished from software assurance processes that may occur during the software development lifecycle of an app. Note that an app vetting process typically involves analysis of an app’s compiled, binary representation but can also involve analysis of the app’s source code if it is available.

answerChoices.Text: Analysis of app’s software development process life cycle
Analysis of app’s source code and language used
Analysis of app’s binary code and source code if available
Analysis of all possible single point failures of the app

questionText: What software testing type verifies that recent changes have not reduced the security or functionality of the software?
explanation: Regression testing takes places after changes are made to the code to ensure the changes have neither reduced functionality or security.

questionText: What are the two steps of formal acceptance of the adequacy of a system’s overall security – also known as accreditation - by the management?
explanation: Certification is the process of evaluating software or a system for its security effectiveness with regard to the customer’s needs. Ratings can certainly be an input to this but are not the only consideration. Accreditation is the formal acceptance of the adequacy of a system’s overall security by the management. Provisional accreditation is given for a specific amount of time and lists required changes to applications, systems, or accreditation documentation. Full accreditation grants accreditation without any required changes.

questionText: What is the LAST step of a system development life cycle (SDLC)?
explanation:
The System Development Life Cycle includes the following phases:

1.         Initiate

2.         Acquire/Develop

3.         Implement

4.         Operate/Maintain

5.         Dispose

When an organization defines new functionality that must be provided either to its customers or internally, it must create systems to deliver that functionality. Many decisions have to be made, and a logical process should be followed in making those decisions. This process is called the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC).

questionText: In which of the following software attacks are actual database commands entered into the database input field?
explanation: Cross site scripting attack: Arises from a vulnerability on a website that allows the attacker to inject malicious code into a web application Buffer overflow: An attack where an invalid amount of input is written to the buffer area SQL injection: When actual database commands are entered into the database input fields instead of the valid input Path traversal: Works by using the ./ characters, entered into the URL to traverse directories that are not supposed to be available from the web

questionText: Input validation is a countermeasure for which attack type?
explanation: The listed attacks can be mitigated with the following countermeasures: TOC/TOU: Make critical sets of instructions atomic. Inference: Polyinstantiation, which is the development of a detailed version of an object from another object using different values in the new object. Buffer overflow: Input validation. Maintenance hooks: Code reviews. Data contamination: Proper implementation of security levels.

questionText: Which term describes a standard for communication between processes on the same computer?
explanation: Component Object Model (COM) is a model for communication between processes on the same computer, while as the name implies, the Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) is a model for communication between processes in different parts of the network.

questionText: Which type of software testing is performed after a change takes place?
explanation: The listed testing types have the following characteristics Regression testing: Tests the functionality, performance, and protection of an application after a change takes place Unit testing: Initial testing that occurs to ensure that individual application components are validated to data structure, logic, and boundary conditions Integration testing: Verifies that application components work together as outlined in the design specifications Acceptance testing: Ensures that the code meets customer requirements

questionText: Which statement applies to the open source software that allows anyone to inspect, modify or enhance the software.
explanation: Open-source software is characterized by its publicly available source code, allowing anyone to inspect, modify, and enhance the software. The open nature of the source code can be a double-edged sword; it allows for greater transparency and the potential for widespread review, which can lead to more secure software.

answerChoices.Text: Anyone can modify and create a subtle bug
Without any transparency it is always secure
Open source software needs compilation by end users
With many widespread reviews it is always bug free

questionText: Which type of software testing ensures customer requirements are met?
explanation: The listed testing types have the following characteristics: Regression testing: Tests the functionality, performance, and protection of an application after a change takes place Unit testing: Initial testing that occurs to ensure that individual application components are validated to data structure, logic, and boundary conditions Integration testing: Verifies that application components work together as outlined in the design specifications Acceptance testing: Ensures that the code meets customer requirements

questionText: What is the BEST advantage developers can derive by incorporating Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) strategy in application development over static or dynamic testing?
explanation: IAST tools provide immediate feedback on security issues as they are identified, allowing developers to address vulnerabilities early in the development process. By incorporating aspects of both SAST and DAST, IAST can offer comprehensive coverage of security vulnerabilities, including those that are only detectable during runtime.

answerChoices.Text: There is no proven advantage compared to static and dynamic testing
It can find mitigate all known Internet vulnerabilities interactively
It provides immediate feedback on security issues as they are identified
It works with network firewall and filter the ingress and egress traffic

questionText: A hacker caused a Denial of Service (DoS) attack with lengthy data submitted on a text box provided on an application. What could have MOSTLY prevented the attack?
explanation:
Buffer Overflow

As discussed in Chapter 5, a buffer is an area of memory where commands and data are placed until they can be processed by the CPU. A buffer overflow occurs when too much data is accepted as input to a specific process. Hackers can take advantage of this phenomenon by submitting too much data, which can cause an error or, in some cases, execute commands on the machine if the hackers can locate an area where commands can be executed. Not all attacks are designed to execute commands. Some just lock up the computer and are used as DoS attacks.

A packet containing a long string of no-operation instructions (NOPs) followed by a command is usually indicative of a type of buffer overflow attack called an NOP slide. The purpose is to get the CPU to locate where a command can be executed. 

In many cases, the key to preventing buffer overflow attacks is input validation. This method requires that any input be checked for format and length before it is used. Buffer overflows and boundary errors (when input exceeds the boundaries allotted for the input) are considered to be a family of error conditions called input validation errors.

Malformed input is the category in which all buffer overflow attacks fit. Malformed input is any attack in which the input is configured in an unusual way.

questionText: In which of the following techniques are group members asked to provide their opinion on a piece of paper in confidence?
explanation: The listed techniques are defined as follows: Gantt chart: Bar charts that represent the progress of tasks and activities over a period of time. PERT: A method used for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project and the time required to complete each task. Delphi technique: Group members are asked to provide their opinion on a piece of paper in confidence. ACID Test: Ensures that each transaction has certain properties before it is committed.
